(CP) - Residents of this remote community straddling the northern Alberta-Saskatchewan boundary fled their homes Friday night as a forest fire crept to within 10 kilometres of them.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Due to the smoke and fire they were going to be evacuating Garson Lake and they're doing that as we speak,'' said RCMP Cpl. Ken Marchand of La Loche, Sask.</p><p>Early reports indicated that 80 people - 40 residents and 40 firefighters - were forced to leave the settlement about 400 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon.</p><p>"The fire is not quite six miles north and on the Alberta border,'' said John Cook of Saskatchewan's forest fire management branch.</p><p>Although La Loche is the nearest community, it only has a winter road to Garson Lake. During the summer, only about two-thirds of the road to Garson Lake is driveable.</p><p>Garson Lake residents are being helicoptered over the heavy bush and rugged Canadian Shield to the end of the road, where they were being met by busses and taken to La Loche.</p><p>Evacuees will likely stay with relatives, said Marchand.</p><p>"I'd be surprised if there was anyone from Garson that didn't have an immediate relative to stay with in La Loche.''</p><p>Earlier Friday, Saskatchewan's environment minister issued a fire ban in the province because of tinder-dry conditions throughout its forests.</p><p>The ban extends from Manitoba to Alberta, north of Highways 3 and 55, and includes all open fires within 4.5 kilometres of provincial forests south of the 58th parallel.</p><p>Only self-contained heating devices or pressurized stoves will be permitted for use during the ban.</p><p>Currently there are approximately 902 firefighters battling 57 fires in the province. Eight of those fires are out of control.</p><p>On Thursday, four elderly residents of the village of Michel evacuated due to smoke returned to their village, according to Joy Adams Bauer, social services spokesperson.</p><p>Michel is located about 60 kilometres south of La Loche and about 55 kilometres east of the Alberta boundary, where a fire has been blazing only five kilometres away for several days.</p><p>No other communities near fires, including La Loche, BlackPoint, Bear Creek, Turner Lake, Ile a la Crosse and Canoe Lake, are in imminent danger.</p><p>The largest fire in the province is a 100-square kilometre blaze near Apps Lake, about half way between Canoe Narrows and Ile a la Crosse. A 70-square kilometre burn is going on just west of Pinehouse.</p><p>Nicholson said the firefighting effort involves 37 helicopters, 13 air tankers, 22 bulldozers and 12 swamp tractors.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5X05-5GJ1-F103-34K6-00000-00Lightning strike causes transformer fire near Williams Lake2019-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSLightning strike causes transformer fire near Williams LakeMonica Lamb-Yorski

A lightning strike near Williams Lake Tuesday evening caused a fire in a hydro transformer.

Residents in the vicinity of the 2200 block of Fox Mountain Road and the 600 block of Mikalusik Road were without power for a few hours.

Wildwood Volunteer Fire Dept. deputy chief Sabrina Dyck said they received a call about the fire around 6:52 p.m. and responded with engine 11, tender 13 and seven firefighters.

"We basically arrived and waited for BC Hydro to attend and disconnect the hydro before we could put out the fire," Dyck said, adding department members were grateful for the heavy rain that was falling because it had been fairly dry a few days before.

"The transformer itself was on fire, but because of the rain I wasn't too concerned about the threat of a forest fire. We did have a lot of concerned people driving by though because of the 2017 wildfires."

The crew returned to the hall just after 9 p.m.

Tuesday's storm was part of a system that swept across the B.C. Interior bringing with it more than 10,000 lightning strikes.

urn:contentItem:5WM3-XPJ1-DY9S-T3XS-00000-00Weather improving: Some Ontario fire evacuees staying in Regina heading home2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNATIONALWeather improving: Some Ontario fire evacuees staying in Regina heading homeSome Ontario fire evacuees heading homeThe Canadian Press

REGINA - Some evacuees who were put up in Regina when they were forced to flee a wildfire in northwestern Ontario are heading home.

Last week, Saskatchewan agreed to welcome about one-quarter of roughly 2,000 members from the Pikangikum First Nation as a forest fire raged near their community.

Rain in the last few days has helped fightfighting crews gain ground on what had been a blaze that covered about 450 square kilometres.

A spokesman for Saskatchewan's public safety agency said about 35 people flew back to their home on Tuesday.

Duane McKay said three or four more flights were planned for Wednesday.

He said there hadn't been official word allowing evacuees staying at the University of Regina to return.

"(We've been) working closely with the local leadership in Ontario, but also with staff that they have sent out here who know the community, know the families," McKay said in a conference call.

"They're identifying people that would be better supported (and) better served there."

Between 200 and 300 evacuees were to remain at the university for the time being, so activities were being planned for the next few days, including sports and a powwow.

"I think everybody's very anxious to get home," McKay said. (CJME)

urn:contentItem:5K67-31S1-JDV5-F0Y2-00000-00NOTL issues complete open-air burning ban2016-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1NOTL issues complete open-air burning ban

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE - Open-air burning is generally not permitted in Niagara-on-the-Lake, but even agricultural operators are told not to have fires.

The town issued an open-air burning ban on Wednesday, with Fire Chief Alex Burbidge issuing a notice that says the ban is in place until further notice. Niagara-on-the-Lake joins a long list of Niagara municipalities with a ban in place.

In general Niagara-on-the-Lake already has restrictions which don't permit residential burns, but agricultural operations usually have authority if approval is obtained in advance for typical burning practices. Even farmers, however, are not permitted to have fires right now, though, to prevent any risk posed by the hot, dry weather.

"We decided until we get some rain we're not going to allow farmers to have fires as well," Burbidge said on Wednesday. "It's essentially nothing is permitted until further notice."

To date, said Burbidge, the town hasn't had to deal with any issues, but they want to ensure they play it safe.

"This is just precautionary," he said.

Burbidge said the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF) has rated the Forest Fire Danger Rating in Niagara as high. They will wait for the weather to cool down, and for sustained rainfall to arrive, in hopes that it will help reduce that rating and lessen the risk.

Burbidge reminds residents that no personal fireworks are to be released as well. He said residents aren't allowed to discharge fireworks at this time anyways, but they are reminded that it is not permitted.

Much of southern Ontario is facing similar warnings in regards to the forest fire danger ratings and there is even an active fire at the Wainfleet bog. Last week the Niagara Peninsula Conservation Authority, in light of various fire bans in the region, restricted access to the bog because of the threat of fire from the continued dry weather. For more forest fire information from the ministry, including what other precautions are advisable with a high rating, see http://bit.ly/1TMXvfR.

Those not following the town's open-air burning bylaw can face fines of up to $50,000 for Ontario Fire Code convictions or cost recovery of $410 minimum per vehicle as per the town's fees for service bylaw. More information on NOTL's open-air burns and other fire safety and prevention materials are available on the town's website, at http://www.notl.org/content/fire-and-emergency-services.

urn:contentItem:5S81-5DT1-F105-609R-00000-00Burn pile escapes and starts fire near McLeese Lake2018-05-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisLOCAL-NEWSBurn pile escapes and starts fire near McLeese LakeTara Sprickerhoff

The McLeese Lake Volunteer Fire Department is asking residents to stop Category 3 open burning after attending a fire that got out of control yesterday afternoon.

"A resident thought it was a good idea to light a burn pile, which quickly got out of control and went into and up the trees," said Fire Chief Ian Hicks in a Facebook post.

"Our goal is to try and stop something small from becoming something big," the chief told the Tribune Thursday.

The fire was located on private property on Forglen road in the McLeese Lake area.

"You can see from the photos that this was a very serious situation - especially in a well-populated area surrounded by thick forest."

"I live right below this fire and was completely unaware of it. You could really only see it from a distance," he said in the post.

The fire fighters used a pumper truck to fill the smaller four-by-four, putting the fire out completely using fire retardant foam.

"I am so proud of my crew and the efforts they put in. This would have become a forest fire for sure and right in the heart of our community."

Hicks told the Tribune if the fire had spread another 30 feet, it would have gotten into underbrush

"Then we would have had a forest fire."

Hicks said people need to stop burning.

"Please guys the time for this is over, I dont care if you think you want to burn something. How are you going to explain that to your neighbours when 50 houses burn down."

The MLVFD said they will be attending anything bigger than a small campfire in the future.

Hicks also said he thinks that the resident was fined.

As of Monday, April 23, Category 3 open fires were banned through the Cariboo Fire Centre area to prevent human-caused wildfires.

"After last summer's disaster we all have to be vigilant and use common sense."

Last summer members of the MLVFD were instrumental in fighting wildfires that threatened areas north of Williams Lake, including the Rankin Ranch.

They're now working to purchase property in order to build a volunteer fire department. Until now, they've worked out of garages and donated property.

"I'm going to be in tears when the thing actually goes up," said Hicks.

urn:contentItem:4706-36C0-01G6-84PK-00000-00<published>1997-05-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>QUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PM-Forest-Fire, ; Eds: UPDATES with main fire under control in para 7, spot fires being worked on; See CP Photos TIM1, TIM2; Forest fire fores hundreds from homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TIMMINS, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>TIMMINS, Ont. (CP) - A state of emergency remained in effect early today after a fire raged through a forest just three kilometres from the heart of this Northern Ontario city.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you almost see the flames from town,'' Ben Legouffe, information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources, said Thursday.</p><p>"I knew right away it was time to get to work.''</p><p>About 500 people - all the residents of two trailer parks along the Mattagami River - were evacuated soon after the fire broke out west of the city at 4:30 p.m. Mayor Vic Power declared a state of emergency about two hours later.</p><p>About 12 homes in the fire's path near Baker Lake were also evacuated and one home was damaged.</p><p>No serious injuries have been reported.</p><p>Early today a firefighter, who declined to be named, said the main fire had been extinguished. This could not be independently confirmed.</p><p>The firefighter said crews were concentrating on putting out spot fires. Evacuees were not permitted to return to their homes in case the wind came up and caused any of the spot fires to flare.</p><p>Burning along a 200-hectare front, the fire jumped the 120-metre wide Mattagami River and a highway.</p><p>Timmins Fire Chief Lester Cudmore said the biggest problem was the wind.</p><p>Crews could not venture into the bush Thursday because the wind posed a danger of crowning - where the fire spreads from treetop to treetop - that could have left firefighters trapped.</p><p>The smoke was so dense firefighters had to regularly be pulled off the line because they couldn't breathe.</p><p>"It's pretty frightening, for sure,'' said police Insp. Ted O'Connor.</p><p>Three water bombers were brought in to help quell the flames from the air while eight crews from local fire departments and the resources ministry worked on the ground.</p><p>At one point the fire raced along the fence surrounding the Malette sawmill. But as firefighters soaked a $7-million inventory of lumber, the blaze veered away.</p><p>Evacuees were taken to a community centre in Timmins.</p><p>"They are pretty upset and concerned,'' Kathy Worman, branch manager of the local Red Cross, said Thursday. "Obviously the fire could destroy everything they own.''</p><p>People managed to gather some valuables before they fled their homes.</p><p>"And we've got a few pets here. We've got a couple of parrots, some dogs and cats. The parrots are talkative but they're keeping the kids amused.''</p><p>Evacuee Edith Pfanner said the thing that bothered her the most was not knowing what was happening.</p><p>"Right now I'm just more or less going on my nerves,'' she said. "This is a day I wish I could go back to bed and sleep right through.''</p><p>Pfanner escaped with her pets and "my mother's 25th anniversary plate. She's been married over 50 years now. Things like that you just grab. Sentimental value.''</p><p>The blaze was the first forest fire of the season in the area but Legouffe of the resources ministry said fires don't usually burn so close to the city.</p><p>Just a year ago, residents along the Mattagami River battled the worst flooding in more than 20 years.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Forty people and two water bombers battled today with a forest fire that had burned within a few kilometres of Goose Bay.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze, which began yesterday afternoon, was burning through trees and scrub near the town of 7,000. It also came within a kilometre of a nearby military radar station.</p><p>The fire is one of five burning in Labrador. Yesterday about 14,000 people in Wabush and Labrador City were without electricity for five hours after flames swept across power lines.</p><p>AIDS tests for kids</p><p>routine, doctor says</p><p>HALIFAX (CP) - Some Canadian doctors are apparently breaking the law by testing children for the AIDS virus without getting consent from either the patients or their parents, a pediatrics conference was told yesterday. Dr. Alan Pyesmany, of the Izaak Walton Killam Children's Hospital in Halifax, said tests for the virus are routine for some patients at the hospital. "In our field, because of the high risk of patients that we deal with, we don't usually ask for special permission to do HIV screening of patients," he said.</p><p>5 arrested in raid</p><p>on hashish factory</p><p>MONTREAL (CP) - Five people have been arrested following a provincial police raid on a hashish-manufacturing operation at a farmhouse in St. Roch-de-l'Achigan, north of Montreal. Police found 20 kilograms (44 pounds) of hash, machinery used in the operation and two guns - the lot worth about $400,000 - in a hangar behind the house.</p><p>1 killed, 1 hurt</p><p>in ultralight crash</p><p>BRANDON, Man. (CP) - A home-made ultralight airplane crashed east of Brandon municipal airport yesterday, killing one man and seriously injuring another. Dead is Daniel Jacob Driedger, 27, of Brandon. Gary Medwechuk, 35, of Douglas, Man., suffered multiple fractures.</p><p>Plagiarism won't cost</p><p>civil servant his job</p><p>SASKATOON (CP) - A Saskatchewan civil servant accused of plagiarism has offered to quit his job, but his resignation won't be accepted. Education Minister Lorne Hepworth revealed that parts of Robert Livingston's 1985 report on deaf schooling were taken from a 1977 article in an American publication. However, after talking to justice officials and academics, Hepworth decided Livingston's transgression deserved disciplinary action but not dismissal.</p><p>Police arrest suspect</p><p>in double slaying</p><p>ANTIGONISH, N.S. (CP) - Charges are pending against a man arrested after two people were killed and another injured in a weekend shooting at nearby Beech Hill. RCMP Staff Sergeant Norm Babcooke identified the dead as John Francis Boucher, 33, and Edmund Wilfred Deon, 48.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4700-NW90-01G6-8264-00000-00<published>1998-05-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Alta-Forest-Fire, ; Fire crews battle forest blazes on two fronts in Alberta</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - While a forest fire south of the town Whitecourt continued to burn out of control Sunday, it was dwarfed by a second fire that was torching 6,000 hectares of woodlands less than 24 hours after it began.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Neither the first fire nor the second, burning east of the town of Slave Lake around Mitsue Lake, were immediately threatening any roads or buildings, said Rick Strickland of the provincial fire centre.</p><p>"There's no immediate threat at this time,'' Strickland said.</p><p>The second fire sparked up some time on Saturday and is being driven eastward by winds gusting to 60 kilometres an hour. By Sunday morning, it was scorching an area 20 kilometres wide and 30 kilometres long.</p><p>The original crew of 24 firefighters was being heavily beefed up, Strickland said.</p><p>Meanwhile, the Whitecourt fire, covering 330 hectares, continued to be fought be 100 firefighters backed up with cats, water trucks and skidders.</p><p>This spring's dry, hot weather had provincial authorities ready for action early, and there has been no problem getting resources to fight the blazes, said Strickland.</p><p>"Early in the season we started to get our resources together,'' he said. "You always sort of anticipate and man up early.''</p><p>At least 163 wild fires had burned in the province in 1998 compared with 29 by this date in 1997.</p><p>Five more fires that burned out of control Saturday were expected to soon be contained.</p><p>Three fires were east of Beaver Lake, 150 kilometres northeast of Edmonton. One was near Worsley in northwestern Alberta. The fifth was close to the large fire outside Niton Junction. (Edmonton Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4702-0K10-01G6-82YM-00000-00<published>1999-05-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Mba-Forest-Fires, ; EDs: PRECEDE; UPDATES with more details; quotes; INDEX: Forestry, Social, Environment; Forest fire forces 600 from homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>BISSETT, Man.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>BISSETT, Man. (CP) - About 600 people fled their homes Sunday as strong winds pushed a forest fire to within kilometres of their communities.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Residents of Seymourville, Hollow Water First Nation and Manigotagan - three small communities clustered on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg - were told to leave their homes late Saturday evening, said Bob Buck of Manitoba Natural Resources.</p><p>-BODY- Unseasonably warm temperatures and winds gusting up to 70 kilometres per hour pushed the blaze to within four kilometres of the communities, about 150 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>Residents went to Bissett, a town about 40 kilometres east of the evacuated area.</p><p>"Everybody's settling in,'' Marlene Wynne said Sunday as she worked the cash register at Wynne's Place, a general store in Bissett.</p><p>"We got more people coming here than actually live here,'' she said.</p><p>Residents were put up at the community hall, school and the town's hotel, said Diana Soroka of Manitoba Emergency Management Organization.</p><p>Another 100 went to Lac du Bonnet, where they will stay at the local Legion hall, she added.</p><p>About 100 left Bissett to stay with family in Winnipeg and other places, Soroka said.</p><p>Buck said the fire - which started Saturday - had grown to 26 kilometres long and two kilometres wide by Sunday. The fire likely was caused by man, he added.</p><p>About 500 firefighters, 30 helicopters and five water bombers were battling the blaze.</p><p>A forest fire also destroyed four homes Saturday in St. Theresa Point, a remote, fly-in community about 400 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>Buck said the fire hazard is extreme in most of Manitoba's forested areas. Temperatures and winds are forecast to drop over the next few days, which will help the crews out fighting the fire, Buck said.</p><p>"But it doesn't look like much rain is coming with it,'' Buck added.</p><p>There were 64 fires burning in Manitoba on Sunday. Twenty new fires started Saturday, all man-made. There is a ban on open fires across the province.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5WJD-Y0R1-JBVR-307G-00000-00Wildfire evacuees from northern Ontario start arriving in Saskatchewan2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisPRAIRIES/BCWildfire evacuees from northern Ontario start arriving in SaskatchewanSaskatchewan welcomes Ontario wildfire evacueesThe Canadian Press

REGINA - Officials in Saskatchewan say some evacuees from forest fires in northwestern Ontario have started arriving in Regina.

The Prairie province has agreed to take about 2,000 residents from the Pikangikum First Nation in Ontario as a growing forest fire rages nearby.

The Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources says the fire has grown to more than 507 square kilometres.

Officials in Saskatchewan say the first flight of evacuees arrived in Regina this morning and another seven flights are scheduled to land today.

Up to 500 evacuees will be taken to the University of Regina dorms and 150 hotel rooms have been booked in the city to accommodate others.

Both Saskatoon and Prince Albert are on standby to receive additional evacuees.

"We are expecting 400 people will be arriving in Regina today by plane," Deanna Valentine, provincial co-ordinator for emergency social services with the Saskatchewan Ministry of Social Services, said during a conference call Thursday.

She said the Red Cross will help evacuees get settled in Regina and the Ontario government is sending interpreters to make sure they are kept informed.

"These people speak mainly Ojibway so the government of Ontario will be sending English and Ojibway interpreters with the evacuees to help with their transition to Saskatchewan and keep them updated on the situation back home."

urn:contentItem:4GV6-WC10-01G6-94X2-00000-00<published>2005-08-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Ontario turns to other provinces for help as forest fire threat widens</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY SHANNON MONTGOMERY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Strafed by more than 150,000 lightning strikes in the space of five days, Ontario's tinder-dry forests were being ravaged by fire Tuesday as officials warned they may not have enough personnel on hand to keep the blazes under control.</p><p nitf:lede="true">There were 147 active forest fires in the province, 63 of which started Monday, and more than 1,500 firefighters on the ground in the battle _ 207 of whom were on loan from the Yukon, the Northwest Territories and the western provinces.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The province has seen twice the number of fires this year as the 10-year average _ but has managed through proactive firefighting to keep them smaller than normal, said Ontario Fire Information Officer Bob Thomas.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The problem isn't the number of fires, it's the number of firefighters, Thomas said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"We don't have enough people to put people on all those fires,'' he said Tuesday from his office in Sault Ste. Marie.</p><p>"We have fires burning with no staff on them.''</p><p>One hundred campers had to be evacuated Monday from the Big Water Lake Campground near Timmins when a nearby blaze got close enough to pose a serious threat.</p><p>The campground's owner, Marian Tremblay, said most of the campers have returned home, although a few were either staying with friends in the area or at nearby hotels.</p><p>Although the fire wasn't directly headed for the campground, erratic winds could have easily blown it off course, Thomas said.</p><p>David Ramsay, the province's natural resources minister, said he's been keeping a close eye on the fire threat, which often depends more on the whims of Mother Nature than anything else.</p><p>"It's a big fire season, it's always a worry,'' Ramsay said. "Especially when you've got weather coming through like we've had.''</p><p>But Ramsay said he's pleased with the way Ontario's firefighters have kept the fires under control so far _ most notably new technology that allows the province to keep closer track of lightning strikes and deal with fires soon after they begin.</p><p>"I think that's why we've had some good success,'' he said. Ontario has seen 43 per cent of the country's forest fires so far this year, but lost less than 2 per cent of the area burned across Canada, Ramsay added.</p><p>"We have a very rapid response.''</p><p>Some provinces, like British Columbia, won't be able to send any more help because they're dealing with their own fire problems.</p><p>The province has one fire out of control that's taking up a lot of resources, and they expect more blazes to crop up in the coming days, said Radha Fisher, B.C.'s provincial fire information officer.</p><p>"We're seeing most of the province in high fire danger, and we're starting to see some areas of extreme,'' Fisher said, adding that more than 130 firefighters are headed back to B.C. for a rest after helping in Ontario's fight.</p><p>"Our indication at this point is to not send anyone right away.''</p><p>All provincial firefighters are managed by a central agency in Winnipeg, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, which monitors needs and surplus across Canada and sends crews accordingly. Ontario has asked for more help, but Thomas said he'd never ask a province to send people it needs at home.</p><p>Ontario's biggest fire is about 100 kilometres north of Thunder Bay, said Thomas, and it's 5,000 hectares in size. It's just one of 50 blazes that are burning out of control across the province, Thomas said.</p><p>The fire that caused Big Water Lake Campground's evacuation, the only one so far to pose a danger to people, was being held steady Tuesday by firefighters, he added.</p><p>Forest fire researcher Tim Lynham of the federal Canadian Forest Service said Canada's fire situation has been about average so far this year.</p><p>In the past couple of years British Columbia has seen some massive fires, but Lynham said the pendulum this year has decided to swing over to Ontario and Quebec, both of which are dealing with bad fire seasons.</p><p>The rest of Canada has stayed relatively fire-free, Lynham said.</p><p>Quebec has seen 800,000 hectares of forest consumed by fires this year, three times more than the 10-year average, said Lynham.</p><p>Ramsay said that last year Ontario sent firefighters across the country to help out British Columbia and Alberta, who are now repaying the favour.</p><p>"We all get our turn, when the weather fluctuates,'' Ramsay said. "It's like a mutual aid system.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4706-36C0-01G6-84PR-00000-00<published>1997-05-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PM-Forest-Fire, ; Eds: UPDATES with main fire under control in para 7, spot fires being worked on; See CP Photos TIM1, TIM2; Forest fire fores hundreds from homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TIMMINS, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>TIMMINS, Ont. (CP) - A state of emergency remained in effect early today after a fire raged through a forest just three kilometres from the heart of this Northern Ontario city.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you almost see the flames from town,'' Ben Legouffe, information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources, said Thursday.</p><p>"I knew right away it was time to get to work.''</p><p>About 500 people - all the residents of two trailer parks along the Mattagami River - were evacuated soon after the fire broke out west of the city at 4:30 p.m. Mayor Vic Power declared a state of emergency about two hours later.</p><p>About 12 homes in the fire's path near Baker Lake were also evacuated and one home was damaged.</p><p>No serious injuries have been reported.</p><p>Early today a firefighter, who declined to be named, said the main fire had been extinguished. This could not be independently confirmed.</p><p>The firefighter said crews were concentrating on putting out spot fires. Evacuees were not permitted to return to their homes in case the wind came up and caused any of the spot fires to flare.</p><p>Burning along a 200-hectare front, the fire jumped the 120-metre wide Mattagami River and a highway.</p><p>Timmins Fire Chief Lester Cudmore said the biggest problem was the wind.</p><p>Crews could not venture into the bush Thursday because the wind posed a danger of crowning - where the fire spreads from treetop to treetop - that could have left firefighters trapped.</p><p>The smoke was so dense firefighters had to regularly be pulled off the line because they couldn't breathe.</p><p>"It's pretty frightening, for sure,'' said police Insp. Ted O'Connor.</p><p>Three water bombers were brought in to help quell the flames from the air while eight crews from local fire departments and the resources ministry worked on the ground.</p><p>At one point the fire raced along the fence surrounding the Malette sawmill. But as firefighters soaked a $7-million inventory of lumber, the blaze veered away.</p><p>Evacuees were taken to a community centre in Timmins.</p><p>"They are pretty upset and concerned,'' Kathy Worman, branch manager of the local Red Cross, said Thursday. "Obviously the fire could destroy everything they own.''</p><p>People managed to gather some valuables before they fled their homes.</p><p>"And we've got a few pets here. We've got a couple of parrots, some dogs and cats. The parrots are talkative but they're keeping the kids amused.''</p><p>Evacuee Edith Pfanner said the thing that bothered her the most was not knowing what was happening.</p><p>"Right now I'm just more or less going on my nerves,'' she said. "This is a day I wish I could go back to bed and sleep right through.''</p><p>Pfanner escaped with her pets and "my mother's 25th anniversary plate. She's been married over 50 years now. Things like that you just grab. Sentimental value.''</p><p>The blaze was the first forest fire of the season in the area but Legouffe of the resources ministry said fires don't usually burn so close to the city.</p><p>Just a year ago, residents along the Mattagami River battled the worst flooding in more than 20 years.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5P01-X3D1-F105-626F-00000-00Campfires banned in Columbia Valley2017-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSCampfires banned in Columbia ValleyLorene Keitch

Campfires have been banned in the region due to high forest fire risks.

Campfires are prohibited throughout the Southeast Fire Centre, to help prevent human-cased wildfires and to protect fire safety, according to the BC Wildfire Service.

Prohibitions on larger category 2 and category 3 open fires were already in effect throughout the southeast fire centre. Spcifically, prhibited activiteis include campfires, stubble or grass fires, the use of fireworks, sky lantersn, tiki torches, chimineas, burning barrels or burning cages of any size or descrption, the use of binary exploding targets or the use of air curtain burners (forced air burning systems).

These prohibitions cover all BC Parks, Crown lands and private lands, but do not apply within the boundaries of a local government that has forest fire prevention bylaws and is serviced by a fire department. Always check with local authorities to see if any other burning restrictions are in place before lighting any fire.

Fines can cost $1,150. Violators of the ban could also be required to pay an administrative penalty of $10,000 or, if convicted in court, be fined up to $100,000 and / or sentaneced to one year in jail. If the contravention causes or contributes to a wildfire, the person responsible may be ordered to pay all firefighting and associated costs, according to the BC Wildfire Service S0uthesast Fire Centre.

To report a wildfire or open burning violation, call 1 800 663-5555 toll-free or *5555 on a cellphone.

For the latest information on current wildfire activity, burning restrictions, road closures and air quality advisories, visit: http://www.bcwildfire.ca You can also follow the latest wildfire news on:

The Southeast Fire Centre covers the area extending from the U.S. border in the south to Mica Dam in the north and from the Okanagan Highlands and Monashee Mountains in the west to the B.C.-Alberta border in the east. It includes the Selkirk Natural Resource District and the Rocky Mountain Natural Resource District.

urn:contentItem:4701-39T0-01G6-81F5-00000-00<published>1998-07-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-NWT-Forest-Fire ; Rain falls on NWT fire but not enough to do much good</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>YELLOWKNIFE</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>YELLOWKNIFE (CP) - A few showers fell on a raging forest fire in the Northwest Territories on Friday but fire officials said it wasn't enough to do any real good.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Any accumulated moisture will dry up over the weekend and leave firefighters back at square one, said fire behavior specialist Rick Lanoville.</p><p>-BODY- "The small amount of rain that we've received is not sufficient to alleviate the serious fire problem,'' Lanoville said.</p><p>"It will give us a little bit of a break to continue work on the fire line and secure what we've established but we're not out of the woods yet.''</p><p>Several people were evacuated from the Tibbet Lake recreation area north of Yellowknife earlier this week because the fire was too close to homes and cabins.</p><p>The blaze covers more than 600 square kilometres, but continues to be held by a fire break 30 kilometres from the territorial capital. The 16,000 residents of Yellowknife are not thought to be in any immediate fire danger.</p><p>The Emergency Measures Organization has been holding public meetings and has set up an information line for residents.</p><p>"People see there's a plan and there's a system in place and the best is being done to fight that fire,'' said EMO spokesman Eric Busey.</p><p>"There are arrangements in place to respond to a risk if it becomes a more immediate concern.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:466N-KK80-01G6-94X3-00000-00<published>2002-07-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Pilot and fire officer died after plane stalled at Alta. forest fire: report</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY STEPHEN TIPPER</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PRINCE ALBERT, Sask. (CP) _ A bird dog'' pilot and a fire attack officer died last year because their plane likely stalled while turning over a raging forest fire north of Edmonton, says a report by the Transportation Safety Board of Canada.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Pilot Grenville Richert of Prince Albert, Sask., had little time to recover before the Air Spray Ltd. Cessna 310 crashed into hilly terrain on May 25, 2001.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Richert and John Graham, a veteran air attack officer from Grande Prairie, Alta., were helping guide water bombers on their runs over the fire 160 kilometres northwest of Slave Lake.</p><p> The aircraft likely entered a stall during a low-level turning manoeuvre from which recovery was not possible,'' said the report.</p><p>The safety board does not assign fault or determine civil or criminal liability. Its report said an examination of the aircraft wreckage revealed no defects that could have led to the accident.</p><p>Several factors were involved during the plane's final manoeuvre, including low relative airspeed, a steep left turn, and a forward centre of gravity, which increases the speed needed to avoid stalling, the report said.</p><p>Richert, 36, was an experienced pilot, having flown more than 10,000 hours in a variety of aircraft. He had been around planes since he was a young boy, his dad having worked for Athabasca Airways as a mechanical engineer.</p><p>It was his first operational flight of the season.</p><p>A bird dog pilot helps plan and check routes to and from the water bomber drop zones, and leads the water bombers into their runs. It is common for bird dog pilots in the Cessna 310 to conduct their low-level operations at low speeds.</p><p>Witnesses said they last observed Richert and Graham making a left turn early that afternoon at about 60 metres above ground level, close to the fire's east flank.</p><p>On hitting the ground, the aircraft cartwheeled and tumbled. An intense fuel-fed fire, which the blaze initiated, consumed the wreckage and spread into the surrounding forest, the report said.</p><p>There was no distress call from the pilot before impact, said the report.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5322-7RG1-DYTJ-12X8-00000-00Thousands ordered to evacuate as mammoth forest fire encroaches on Arizona town2011-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSThousands ordered to evacuate as mammoth forest fire encroaches on Arizona townBOB CHRISTIE,SUSAN MONTOYA BRYANAP

SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz. _ Flames from a mammoth forest fire licked the ridges surrounding the eastern Arizona town of Eagar, forcing the evacuation of about half the 4,000 residents as surrounding towns also prepared to empty.

People started streaming out of Eagar on Tuesday as sheriff's deputies and police officers directed traffic. Flames were spotted on a ridge on the southeastern side of nearby Springerville and columns of orange smoke rose from the hills. Ash rained from the sky, which was filled with thick smoke, and when the sun peeked through, it was blood-red.

Angie Colwell, her husband Mike and their two children were loading up their belongings as authorities ordered their Eagar neighbourhood to evacuate.

''We love the mountains and we're just afraid of what's going to be left after the fire comes through,'' the longtime resident said.

The blaze has burned 486 square miles (1,259 square kilometres) of ponderosa pine forest, driven by wind gusts of more than 60 mph (96 kph) since it was sparked May 29 by what authorities believe was an unattended campfire. On Tuesday, it became the second-largest fire in Arizona history.

No serious injuries have been reported, but the fire has destroyed 10 structures so far. It has cast smoke as far east as the state of Iowa and forced some planes to divert from Albuquerque, New Mexico, some 200 miles (320 kilometres) away.

Joe Reinarz, commander of a firefighting team battling the so-called Wallow fire, told residents Tuesday night that the fire was within two miles (three kilometres) of Springerville and Eagar.

Crews were trying to keep the flames away from Eagar and Springerville law enforcement officers patrolled the evacuated areas.

The Apache County sheriff's office issued the evacuation order for areas south of state Route 260 and east of Greer just before 4 p.m.

Eagar has about 4,000 residents, while Springerville has another 2,000. In all, about 7,000 people have been ordered to prepare for evacuation in recent days.

Several tiny resort towns in the nearby Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest were evacuated earlier. Winds whipping the fire Monday drove the last holdouts from Greer.

Earlier in the day, bulldozers scraped away brush and trees to create a barrier between the towns and the approaching flames in the surrounding mountains. Other crews removed brush from around homes and firefighters were sent to protect buildings from the flames.

Thousands of firefighters, including many from several western states and as far away as New York, hope to keep the flames from getting into Springerville and Eagar, which sit in grassland at the edge of the forest.

With a blaze as large as this being driven by unpredictable and gusty winds, putting the fire out is a gargantuan task. All fire managers can do is try to steer it away from homes and cabins by using natural terrain, burning out combustible material first and trying to put out spot fires sparked by embers blowing in front of the main fire front.

New mapping showed that some firebreaks have held but the wildfire was still considered zero per cent contained Tuesday night.

The American Red Cross has an evacuation centre at the high school about 15 miles (24 kilometres) west in Lakeside, Arizona, that can handle several thousand people, spokesman Mark Weldon said.

Haze was being carried by a ridge of high pressure as far as central Iowa, said Kyle Fredin, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Denver. The smoke was also visible in New Mexico, Colorado, Nebraska and Kansas.

Colorado health officials cancelled a smoke health advisory Tuesday as smoke cleared from the southern half of the state. Two airliners headed to Albuquerque were diverted Monday night because of smoke and high winds.

The state's largest blaze came in 2002 when flames blackened more than 732 square miles (1,895.square kilometres) and destroyed 491 homes. A fire in 2005 burned about 387 square miles (1,002 square kilometres) in the Phoenix suburb of Cave Creek and consumed 11 homes.

Another major wildfire was burning in southeastern Arizona, threatening two communities. The 166-square-mile (430-square-kilometre) blaze has devoured three summer cabins and four outbuildings since it started May 8.

Christie reported from Phoenix.

urn:contentItem:5W3D-HX11-JDH1-C059-00000-00UPDATE : Crews gaining control of Sayward fire2019-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSUPDATE : Crews gaining control of Sayward fire

The forest fire in the Village of Sayward is now 30 per cent contained, BC Wildfire Service says.

A fire fighting crew of 30 members was sent this morning to start tackling the fire. This included heavy machinery and four helicopters.

The fire had reached 8 ha. in size, at last indication and crews and emergency personnel battled the fire from the ground and the air yesterday. BC Wildfire is expecting to have it contained by tonight or tomorrow.

The Sayward Fire Department and the BC Wildfire Service were called to the fire in Sayward on Friday morning.

The fire started burning in some slash near the Village of Sayward on Friday morning and the Coastal Fire Centre indicated it grew to approximately 6.5 hectares in size by Friday evening in an area adjacent to Frenchman Road in Sayward, 76 kilometres northwest of Campbell River.

The Sayward Fire Department was engaged in battling the fire with the Coastal Fire Centre providing assistance to them. Coastal Fire had 12 firefighters, an officer and two helicopters on the scene in addition to Sayward firefighters, the Coastal Fire Centre said. BC Wildfire Service says the fire is human-caused.

There was some concern late yesterday that expected windy conditions today would hamper attempts to control the fire.

urn:contentItem:3WJ6-1HS0-00RK-C4CB-00000-00<published>1986-06-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. A17</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Military paying victims of forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>(CP)</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>OTTAWA</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>OTTAWA (CP) - Government compensation cheques will start going out next week to people whose property was damaged by a forest fire caused by the military at a base in New Brunswick.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Associate defence minister Harvie Andre told the House of Commons yesterday, that an inquiry has established the defence department was responsible for the fire, which was caused by artillery fire in a tinder-dry area of forest on Canadian Forces Base Gagetown.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Some 75 claims were made for compensation, worth more than $1 million.</p><p>Western drug chain</p><p>yanks adult magazines</p><p>VANCOUVER (CP) - London Drugs has ordered adult magazines yanked from its 25 stores in British Columbia and Alberta, saying they will be banned "until the distributors or their publishers wrap them to leave only the titles exposed." Mark Nussbaum, senior vice-president, said that after many complaint letters he looked at some of the magazines and found "some of the pictures and the articles have got out of hand."</p><p>Saskatchewan doctors</p><p>okay new fee deal</p><p>REGINA (CP) - Saskatchewan doctors have voted 95 per cent in favor of accepting an agreement worked out earlier this month with the province. Dr. Craig Hubbard, president of the Saskatchewan Medical Association, president said the deal will provide $5.8 million for the provincial fund that pays for doctors' services. Another $4.2 million will be paid by the province in two instalments for other adjustments in the fee schedule.</p><p>Ottawa orders probe</p><p>of B.C.Indian band</p><p>OTTAWA (CP) - A commission of inquiry will be appointed to investigate the affairs of the WestbankIndian band in Kelowna, B.C., Indian Affairs Minister David Crombie says.</p><p>Defied prayer rules,</p><p>teen still harassed</p><p>MACGREGOR, Man. (CP) - A teenager who created a stir in this rural southwestern Manitoba community for refusing to stand for the Lord's Prayer was plagued by at least 75 harassing phone calls just before his high school graduation this week. "It's really quite scary coming from a civilized religious community," said Sandra Tait, mother of 17-year-old Chris Tait. Her son was temporarily suspended in January for remaining seated during prayers. His schoolmates then decided to replace him as valedictorian at the ceremony.</p><p>Court allows review</p><p>of rail station closing</p><p>OTTAWA (CP) - The Canadian Transport Commission has the authority to consider what impact closing a railway station might have upon the remote Northern Ontario town of Nakina, the Federal Court of Appeal has ruled. The court said said it was startled by the commission's conclusion that it was not entitled to take into account the local economic effect of Canadian National Railway's plan to close its station in the town several hundred kilometres northeast of Thunder Bay.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4702-0MM0-01G6-8165-00000-00<published>1999-06-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Sask-Fire-Evacuation ; INDEX: Social, Forestry; Residents go home after rains abate forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>LA RONGE, Sask.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>LA RONGE, Sask. (CP) - About 50 residents of the tiny northern Saskatchewan community of Garson Lake were back home Tuesday after a forest fire forced them to leave for several days.</p><p>"Everything went smoothly,'' said Joy Adams Bauer of Saskatchewan Emergency Services.</p><p>"It's almost life as usual - (evacuation) happens fairly regularly and people take it in stride.''</p><p>-BODY- No one was hurt. No buildings were damaged, although the flames came within one kilometre of the community.</p><p>Heavy rains of more than 30 millimetres throughout most of northern Saskatchewan have dampened the flames, said John Cook of the provincial fire centre in Prince Albert.</p><p>"We've had good rainfall right across the southern part of the northern provincial forest,'' he said. "In general, things are looking very good.''</p><p>Although Saskatchewan still has 44 fires, all are under control - including the 13 new fires started by the lightning that accompanied the rain.</p><p>In Alberta, firefighters are welcoming a similar soggy outlook.</p><p>A heavy rainfall warning was issued Tuesday for the Wood Buffalo National Park in the province's far north, where a blaze has destroyed nearly 600 square kilometres of forest.</p><p>The blaze has nearly tripled in size over the last three days, but doesn't pose any threat to recreational areas or settlements.</p><p>The fire was burning in the southeast corner on the Alberta side of the park, about 80 kilometres from Fort Smith, N.W.T.</p><p>Fort Smith is expected to get about 50 millimetres of rain by today.</p><p>Park officials are hoping the same system will work its way south and dump needed moisture on the fire.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4702-0K30-01G6-83S0-00000-00<published>1999-05-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PM-Forest-Fires, Bgt ; WPG OUT WQQ; Budget; INDEX: Environment; Forest-fire evacuees save treasures</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kimberly Hicks</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal</p><p nitf:lede="true">THUNDER BAY, Ont. (CP) - Diane Butay was almost out the door of her home when she noticed a tiny white porcelain shoe passed down from her great-grandmother.</p><p nitf:lede="true">She gently removed it from a shelf and placed it in her bag.</p><p>-BODY- The shoe is a priceless family heirloom that could never be replaced if her home is claimed by a forest fire that was quickly closing in on the Beardmore community.</p><p>"My daughter is expecting this summer, and it goes to my daughter's daughter,'' said Butay as tears welled up in her eyes.</p><p>The Ministry of Natural Resources declared much of Northern Ontario a restricted fire zone as more than four-dozen fires raged across the area.</p><p>The largest fire, a 10,000-hectare blaze, led to the evacuation Tuesday of Beardmore, near Lake Nipigon.</p><p>About 300 residents were taken to Geraldton, about 80 kilometres to the east, and at least seven lakeside cottages were destroyed by the blaze.</p><p>A 500-hectare blaze near Chapleau is burning out of control and a 60-hectare fire was burning about 25 kilometres north of Hornepayne.</p><p>Recent mild winter, an early snow melt, a lack of spring rain and unseasonably warm temperatures have all contributed to the fire hazard.</p><p>Butay had been packing clothing since she was told of the evacuation alert Sunday. But as the fire closed in on the northwestern Ontario community, she began to pack up things in her house that she knew couldn't be replaced.</p><p>She also had to leave her two dogs and two cats behind because no pets are allowed at the emergency centres.</p><p>"I couldn't bring my pets on the bus and I just sat there and cried,'' said Butay.</p><p>She was told that if the fire makes it to the community, the animals will be released to fend for themselves.</p><p>In Sioux Lookout, Ont., a fire is about four kilometres from the community of Bearskin Lake.</p><p>A wooden hydro pole burned by a forest fire resulted in power being cut to the town of White River and the three Hemlo gold mines Tuesday afternoon.</p><p>Another stubborn fire south of Temagami continued to burn. The fire began Sunday afternoon and forced more than 20 people to evacuate their homes. They returned Monday.</p><p>In Manitoba, firefighters cautiously claimed victory over a massive fire east of Lake Winnipeg.</p><p>Fire boss Ken Ulrich said while the fire near Manigotagan continues to be officially classified as "out of control,'' workers have successfully contained it.</p><p>"It's a sleeping giant right now,'' Ulrich said Tuesday in Pine Falls. "It hasn't expanded any, but we'll have to watch the weather.''</p><p>It forced more than 600 people from their homes and destroyed the Rice River Bridge across Highway 304. No homes were damaged.</p><p>Another fire near the Island Lake reserve of St. Theresa Point, about 500 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg, forced the 57 people out of their homes on Sunday.</p><p>(Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal; Winnipeg Free Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5W36-JN31-JDH1-C4YV-00000-00UPDATE : Crews gaining control of Sayward fire2019-05-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSUPDATE : Crews gaining control of Sayward fireAlistair Taylor

The forest fire in the Village of Sayward is now 30 per cent contained, BC Wildfire Service says.

A fire fighting crew of 30 members was sent this morning to start tackling the fire. This included heavy machinery and four helicopters.

The fire had reached 8 ha. in size, at last indication and crews and emergency personnel battled the fire from the ground and the air yesterday. BC Wildfire is expecting to have it contained by tonight or tomorrow.

The Sayward Fire Department and the BC Wildfire Service were called to the fire in Sayward on Friday morning.

The fire started burning in some slash near the Village of Sayward on Friday morning and the Coastal Fire Centre indicated it grew to approximately 6.5 hectares in size by Friday evening in an area adjacent to Frenchman Road in Sayward, 76 kilometres northwest of Campbell River.

The Sayward Fire Department was engaged in battling the fire with the Coastal Fire Centre providing assistance to them. Coastal Fire had 12 firefighters, an officer and two helicopters on the scene in addition to Sayward firefighters, the Coastal Fire Centre said. BC Wildfire Service says the fire is human-caused.

There was some concern late yesterday that expected windy conditions today would hamper attempts to control the fire.

urn:contentItem:470N-T7T0-01G6-83GX-00000-00<published>1994-07-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Forest-Fire-Paper ; VCR OUT VQQ; Hiker starts fire trying to burn garbage</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>LYTTON, B.C.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>LYTTON, B.C. (CP) - A hiker trying to tread lightly is the suspected cause of a 100-hectare forest fire in the pristine Stein River Valley west of here.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A Forests Ministry official said Wednesday three parties hiking in the Stein told investigators that another hiker accidently started the blaze.</p><p>"A hiker was trying to burn his or her toilet paper,'' fire control officer Verne Rasmussen said Wednesday.</p><p>"I guess they didn't want to leave any garbage. We have to live with the results.''</p><p>So now a fire burns in a dry Ponderosa pine forest in the largest unlogged watershed near the Greater Vancouver that was the focus of high-profile environmental campaigns and celebrity-supported wilderness festivals during the late 1980s.</p><p>Water bombers hit the fire after it was first reported Sunday.</p><p>Rasmussen said the fire is still officially classified as uncontrolled because it is not completely surrounded by fire guards or barren strips of ground, but at least the the fire is not getting larger.</p><p>About 40 people were trying to contain the fire, about 160 kilometres northeast of Vancouver.</p><p>Rasmussen said the government investigation may never identify the person responsible for the blaze or confirm the cause.</p><p>He suggested that any hiker wanting to burn toilet paper should use extreme caution, but questioned the need to burn the paper in the first place.</p><p>"What's a few sheets of toilet paper?'' he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7WVP-WJC1-2R6R-51BR-00000-00Forest fire on Greek island prompts evacuation of French tourists2009-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSForest fire on Greek island prompts evacuation of French touristsNICHOLAS PAPHITISCP

ATHENS _ A large blaze swept through a pine forest on the Greek island of Evia Tuesday, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of French tourists from a nearby hotel, officials said.

All 426 French nationals were safely taken away by ferry from the Club Med hotel near Aidipsos in northern Evia, about 80 miles (130 kilometres) northwest of Athens, a fire department spokesman said.

''Nobody was hurt,'' the spokesman said on customary condition of anonymity.

The French tourists were heading for the mainland town of Aghios Constantinos. They were evacuated as a precaution after flames cut off road access to their hotel.

The fire department spokesman said the blaze was moving toward the nearby village of Gialtra, but homes were not under immediate threat.

The cause of the fire, which started around 3 p.m. (1200 GMT), was under investigation. The flames quickly spread because of very strong winds that followed days of unseasonably high temperatures.

More than 70 firefighters were battling the blaze, assisted by 23 fire trucks, while seven water-dropping aircraft that initially helped firefighters on the ground had to withdraw after nightfall.

Reinforcements of 60 more firefighters from other parts of Greece were expected.

Evia, just off the Greek mainland, was struck by wildfires in August that destroyed two homes and swathes of forest land. A few weeks later, flash floods in burnt areas left one dead, while damaging dozens of homes and businesses, cutting off main roads and destroying a bridge.

The island also suffered in the major fires that burnt through central and southern Greece in 2007, leaving 76 dead.

urn:contentItem:48W7-PS60-01G6-928T-00000-00<published>2003-06-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hundreds of residents of Fort MacKay, Alta. evacuated due to forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FORT MACKAY, Alta. (CP) _ Hundreds of residents were forced from their homes Wednesday when a forest fire burned to within five kilometres of their northern Alberta hamlet.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The out-of-control blaze was south of the tiny community, about 400 kilometres north of Edmonton when officials told the 260 residents to leave about 3 p.m. local time. Strong winds were fanning the fire westward, said provincial fire officials.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>But not everyone felt the need to leave.</p><p>While most people rushed to leave, Bernadette Gladue, 52, said she decided to stay in her home with her six-month-old granddaughter.</p><p>"People were panicking and I asked them, 'For what?','' she said. "I was watering my lawn when everyone was passing by.''</p><p>Gladue said she's seen a fair number of forest fires over the years and this one is not close enough for her to worry about.</p><p>"Not for five kilometres, I won't run away for that.''</p><p>Gladue said she could see big clouds of smoke south of the hamlet but the air was fine, not smoky, even six hours after the hamlet was evacuated.</p><p>The fire blackened 1.4 square kilometres of forest and heavy smoke forced the closure of Highway 63, the main highway in and out of the community. The Mildred Lake airstrip had to close due to the blaze, says a news release from Alberta Sustainable Resources.</p><p>As well, about 1,300 Syncrude employees working at its Aurora mine site were stuck at work due to the highway closure, said Randy Provencale, spokesman for the crude oil producer.</p><p>But the oilsands company got a convoy of 15 buses to transport their stranded employees on the smoky highway back to their homes in Fort McMurray, Provencale said.</p><p>"We are in the process of getting them out,'' he said. "But we are not sure how long that process is going to take because there are a lot of vehicles lined up.''</p><p>"We are monitoring it, but our intention is to have our day-shift out there if we can.''</p><p>The fire was also near the northern boundary of Syncrude's main plant, said Rick Strickland, provincial forestry spokesman.</p><p>The 260 residents of Fort MacKay, along with residents on the nearby First Nations reserve and 100 workers from an area oil camp, were taken by buses to a hockey rink in Fort McMurray.</p><p>"We just finished renovating our house,'' said Donnelly Alook, who was seeking refuge at the rink.</p><p>"We put a lot of work into that house. And I left my car at home and hope the fire doesn't go close and blow up the house.''</p><p>Calvin Kennedy, who also left his home and was at the rink, praised the firefighters.</p><p>"The fire crews are doing a really good job out there. There are guys on standby if worse comes to worse.''</p><p>It's not known how fast the fire was burning but strong winds and 30 C temperatures were hampering firefighting efforts, said Strickland.</p><p>A thunderstorm was expected Wednesday evening but officials were unsure of how much rain it would bring. Lightning starting new fires was also a concern, Strickland said.</p><p>Seven air tankers, five helicopters and 18 firefighters were battling the blaze. Syncrude also sent two water trucks to help with the blaze, Strickland said.</p><p>However, conditions slowed down some of the firefighting equipment.</p><p>"There was heavy black smoke that really reduced our efforts with the air tankers,'' Strickland said.</p><p>Bulldozers were also digging a protective trench around the community.</p><p>It is not known when the residents will be able to return to their homes.</p><p>"They are temporarily evacuated until it is safe to return to the community,'' said Angela McGonigal, spokeswoman for the regional municipality of Wood Buffalo.</p><p>Another forest fire Wednesday near Prince Albert, Sask., north of Saskatoon, was burning out-of-control.</p><p>The fire had grown to more than half a square kilometre but winds pushed the fire away from surrounding communities and there were no evacuations.</p><p>In May 2002, a fire south of Fort McMurray forced the closure of Highway 63 for two days leaving residents stranded.</p><p>In 1999, a fire north of Fort McMurray again closed Highway 63 and cut two oilsand mines off from the city.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4706-DYT0-01G6-837T-00000-00<published>1997-12-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Forest-Fire, ; EDS: ADDS grass fire and evacuations in southern Alberta; Families evacuated from forest fire in foothills; grass fire on plains</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>HINTON, Alta.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>HINTON, Alta. (CP) - Several families were evacuated from their homes Sunday after forest and grass fires flared up in separate areas of the Alberta foothills.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Near Hinton, about 300 kilometres west of Edmonton, a pair of forest fires began late Saturday night and were still burning Sunday.</p><p>And a grass fire that began west of Pincher Creek in the southwest corner of the province early Sunday morning closed Highway 2 north to Calgary and forced families out of their homes near the community of Granum.</p><p>Barbara Wurtz from of the Keho Hutterite colony said women and children had been evacuated to another colony north of Granum while the men remained to work on saving a pig barn at risk from the blaze.</p><p>"While the sun was out we could see what seemed like a mixture of billowing sand and smoke,'' said Eileen Cooper of Barons, a town just east of Granum.</p><p>"At one time the sun was rust-red.''</p><p>Three buildings were burned north of Hinton, said Evert Smith of Alberta's Land and Forest Service Sunday afternoon.</p><p>"We don't know whether they were houses or outbuildings,'' said Smith.</p><p>"No other structures are in immediate danger. (The families) were evacuated as a precaution.''</p><p>They were fleeing a fire covering 500 hectares that burned about 15 kilometres northwest of Hinton. A second fire, about 1,500 hectares in size, blazed about 30 kilometres south of the town.</p><p>Although the fires were being driven by 80-kilometre winds, neither was expected to menace the community of about 10,000. The wind, however, was hampering firefighting efforts, said Smith.</p><p>"At this time, we're limited to ground action due to high winds,'' he said.</p><p>The Pincher Creek fire department said the grass fire started west of the town and headed north. Sixteen firefighting units from the surrounding area were working on the blaze.</p><p>Smoke was blowing over 30 kilometres to the town of Granum and farmyards. Farmer Ray Dunlop and his family left their farm house southwest of Granum about 3 p.m. Sunday afternoon because of the smoke.</p><p>The causes of the fires have not yet been determined, Smith said.</p><p>Although most forest fires occur in the summer, winter fires do occur along the foothills, areas often blown bare and dry by chinook winds gusting over the mountains.</p><p>"Along the eastern slopes, we have records of fires in all 12 months of the year,'' said Smith.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5T6F-KJ51-F103-333Y-00000-00Northwest B.C. residents help relocate and feed animals displaced by fires2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSNorthwest B.C. residents help relocate and feed animals displaced by fires

The Lakes Animal Friendship Society (LAFS) has raised over $16,000 to provide care for pets affected by wildfires, thanks to generous community donations and matching from an anonymous private donor.

According to LAFS director Alistair Schroff, these donations are helping with the transport, shelter, feeding and other needs of animals in the Burns Lake area.

Since the wildfire season began, LAFS has found spots for dozens of cats and dogs through their network of volunteers.

"This includes some difficult cases like kittens who still need to be socialized because they are from community cats," said Schroff.

This work will likely continue even after the wildfire season is over, according to Schroff.

"The current crisis is not over, as the fires continue to grow and affect additional families," he said. "How long families and their pets will remain evacuated is not known; and even after the fires have subsided we still have to get people home and meet the needs of their companion animals in the recovery period."

"We also want folks to recognize that this disaster is far from over and will affect animals and their families in the weeks and months ahead, and beyond," he continued. "There are a lot of mental, physical and financial stresses involved for all as our lands, homes and livelihoods are impacted."

"These things affect our furry family members and we have to be ready for the extra needs we will face," he added.

Some of LAFS' biggest donors include the Burns Lake Community Forest, Paws for Hope and Lakes District Maintenance – each contributing $1,000.

"But we also have donations coming from concerned folks across North America."

The animal organization has also been partnering with other groups and businesses such as the Lakes District Food Bank, Burns Lake Community Forest, Burns Lake Veterinary Clinic, Emergency Social Services and Amanda's Pampered Paws to ensure local animals are having their needs met.

In addition, LAFS has received support from the BC SPCA, The Postmen, L'il Red Pony Feed and Supplies in Quesnel, the Canadian Disaster Animal Response Team, and Loved at Last Dog Rescue. These groups are helping with needed supplies such as transport crates and food, which Schroff says will help stretch donor dollars further.

To donate to LAFS, visit https://www.lakesanimalfriendship.ca/shop/donate/.

More volunteers needed

While donations are hugely important, Schroff says it takes volunteers to "actually make stuff happen."

"Our local volunteers have been amazing in helping get the critters what they need, when they need it, which can be a challenge when you have evacuation orders and other logistical nightmares to deal with," he said.

According to Schroff, having more volunteers – including foster families – would make a big difference right now.

"We would love to have more, as we never have enough, even in normal times," he said. "Cash donations are also great because they can be used to fill whatever need comes up."

Other donations such as food, crates and supplies can be dropped off at P & B Feeds in Burns Lake.

"With the right resources we will be able to keep doing what we can to help keep everyone happy and healthy."

Northerners helping northerners

A Facebook Page created by a northwest B.C. resident called 'Northwest Forest Fire Support Network' is dedicated to helping families and livestock displaced by wildfires in B.C. find temporary space until they can return home or rebuild.

Help is coming in many forms through this Facebook page – from the transportation of livestock evacuating a wildfire area to finding them temporary homes, to organizing feed for these animals and raising funds to feed all this livestock.

People have flocked to this Facebook page to post photos of their corals, pastures and chicken coops to open them up for evacuated animals.

Houston resident Deanna Bell has been instrumental in this effort. She has also set up a a Go Fund Me campaign called 'Northwest forest fire support,' which had raised over $11,000 by Thursday.

So far, between Bell handling the larger animals and Jason Jubinville from P & B Feeds in Burns Lake, who is handling the smaller ones, they've relocated over 1,200 animals.

READ MORE: Houston joins forces with Burns Lake

"So far, donations have been amazing," Jubinville told Lakes District News, adding that lots of hay is still needed.

A donation account has also been set up at the Bulkley Valley Credit Union called 'Northwest forest fire support.'

For more information on how to donate, contact Deanna Bell at 250-845-9595 or Jason Jubinville at 250-692-3276.
