A03</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo><nitf:fixture xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/">News</nitf:fixture></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Wild forest fire near Ottawa forces residents from homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>ALMONTE</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Dozens of homes were evacuated Wednesday as firefighters and water bomber pilots raced to squelch a forest fire burning out of control just west of Ottawa.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire trucks from 12 municipalities lined Highway 44 outside this picturesque village about 50 kilometres from the capital as two airplanes dumped water from the sky.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The fire is too hot to attack it on the ground," said Paul Asmis, fire chief for West Carleton Township. "(It's) crowning and jumping ahead of itself in 500-foot (150-metre) intervals."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CANADIAN PRESS</p></bodyText></section><p>Provincial police officer Neil Fennell said late Wednesday that firefighters were in "a holding pattern."</p><p>Two water bombers from Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources were on the scene during the day. They quit after dark Wednesday but were expected to resume their runs at daylight.</p><p>At least one water bomber was brought in from Quebec.</p><p>The blaze broke out around 1 p.m. and moved at about 3 1/2 kilometres an hour along a six-kilometre stretch comprised mostly of bush and forest, consuming more than 150 hectares of land.</p><p>It moved easterly at first but veered north as the wind shifted.</p><p>More than 120 firefighters tried to keep it from reaching a residential enclave about nine kilometres east of where it started, said a dispatcher.</p><p>"I think we're getting some progress on it but it's hard to tell right now, said Chris Powers, chief of the Nepean Fire Department near Ottawa.</p><p>Protective foam was sprayed on about 30 houses in the fire's path as fire trucks stood by.</p><p>"It's still a dangerous situation," Powers said as the evening wore on.</p><p>Richard MacLean, his wife and two of his three children sat in lawn chairs a safe distance away, watching flames creep toward their home in nearby Carp.</p><p>"I'm very worried," he said. "I spent a good part of the winter clearing trees in there. I must have cut 300 or 400 trees from the ice storm last year."</p><p>Police told MacLean and his family to leave their home, which they did after turning off the power.</p><p>"You're worried. Your house is your castle."</p><p>Smoke could be seen for kilometres and ash from the fire was falling as far away as Kanata, a western suburb of Ottawa.</p><p>There were no reports of injuries and no homes had been destroyed by late Wednesday.</p><p>Some evacuees were taken to an arena in Carp and it remained uncertain when they would be allowed to go back home.</p><p>"The fire is . . . definitely not under control by any means," said one OPP officer. "No word yet on how long it might take."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>CANADIAN PRESS; Volunteer firefighters battle a brush fire in Almonte, near Ottawa, Wednesday. Two helicopters, plus fire trucks from six municipalities, battled the blaze.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4706-DYT0-01G6-837X-00000-00<published>1997-12-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Forest-Fire, ; EDS: CHANGES placeline to undated; ADDS quotes, details on fire-fighting effort, state of evacuation at Granum; Families evacuated from forest fire in foothills; grass fire on plains</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By The Canadian Press</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Two raging forest fires and an out-of-control brush fire burned several homes in west-central Alberta and forced the evacuation of a small town in the province's south Sunday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Near Hinton, about 300 kilometres west of Edmonton, a handful of ranches were destroyed by a blaze believed to have started late Saturday night when an electrical pole toppled over and sparked grass left tinder-dry by the warm weather and snow-free conditions this winter.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We just woke up because the house was filling with smoke,'' said Rocky Notnes, who lost his two-storey log home, several cars and a garage to the fire.</p><p>"We went outside and saw the fire. The wind was so strong we knew it could come this way, and then as we were speaking, there was just fire literally dropping from the sky.''</p><p>On Sunday afternoon, the entire population of Granum, a town of about 350 in southwestern Alberta, was ordered evacuated as a grass fire burned unchecked.</p><p>The blaze, which fire officials said had burned 100 square kilometres of land, also forced the closure of Highway 2 and prompted women and children to flee the Keho Hutterite colony.</p><p>Spokeswoman Barbara Wurtz said colony members evacuated to another colony north of Granum while the men stayed behind to work on saving a pig barn.</p><p>"While the sun was out we could see what seemed like a mixture of billowing sand and smoke,'' said Eileen Cooper of Barons, a town just east of Granum.</p><p>"At one time the sun was rust-red.''</p><p>Visitors and workers at a popular tourist attraction called Head-Smashed-In-Buffalo-Jump were also evacuated as a precaution.</p><p>Near Hinton, Evert Smith of Alberta's Land and Forest Service said one of the two fires covered 500 hectares north of the community. The second blaze, about 1,500 hectares in size, blazed about 30 kilometres south of the town.</p><p>Although the fires were being driven by 80-kilometre winds, neither was expected to menace the community of about 10,000.</p><p>Six water tankers, four helicopters and eight ground crews were fighting the fires.</p><p>In southern Alberta, about 60 evacuated residents of Granum took shelter in the high school gymasium at nearby Claresholm while the rest stayed with friends or family.</p><p>Mayor Ernie Patterson said members of church and business organizations in the town brought food for supper.</p><p>"We've had no snow,'' Patterson said of local conditions. "The forest fire hazard is extremely high.'' Sixteen different fire departments in different communities were fighting the grass fire.</p><p>Lethbridge fire platoon chief Don Carpenter said Sunday afternoon he didn't know who's in control.</p><p>Forestry officer Dennis Halladay said every jurisdiction was fighting it on their own: "We'll look later this evening to see if we'll continue that way or pull it all together.''</p><p>Although most forest fires occur in the summer, winter fires do occur along the foothills, areas often blown bare and dry by chinook winds gusting over the mountains.</p><p>"Along the eastern slopes, we have records of fires in all 12 months of the year,'' said Smith.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Mother Nature dampens B.C.'s explosive forest fire season, says minister</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY DIRK MEISSNER</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VICTORIA (CP) _ Mother Nature's timely rains and cool temperatures this past summer likely saved British Columbia from a second disastrous forest fire season in a row, Forests Minister Mike de Jong said Tuesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Rains and cool temperatures luckily arrived at times when firefighters needed help most, especially early in the season when the blazes weren't expected, he said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We got some significant help from Mother Nature,'' de Jong said at a press briefing reviewing the fire season.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The government feared last June that British Columbia was on its way toward a repeat of 2003 when wild fires forced the evacuation of thousands of people in the southern Interior and cost the province $372 million.</p><p>Hundreds of homes in a Kelowna neighbourhood were destroyed by fire and the communities of Louis Creek, Barriere and McLure were ravaged.</p><p>The property damage caused by forest fires in 2004 was nowhere near as disastrous _ only one historic homestead in the Cariboo region near Williams Lake was destroyed _ but the potential for danger had everybody planning for the worst, de Jong said.</p><p>"It looked as if we were going to have exactly the same kind of fire season we had in 2003, only it was going to start six weeks earlier,'' said de Jong. "There was great concern at that point about where this was all headed.''</p><p>The June fires in the Lillooet area, which had the Interior community on evacuation notice for weeks, had firefighters on a level of alert similar to what "existed in the early stages of the Battle of Britain. It was pretty tense,'' de Jong said.</p><p>Lillooet's 4,000 residents were told to pack their vehicles with valuables and be prepared to flee in minutes as fires from two directions raced down steep mountainsides toward the community, he said.</p><p>"It looked like Saigon in there for a week,'' de Jong said. "It really did. At one point (the fire) was two kilometres from town.''</p><p>A major lesson the Forests Ministry will take from this year's fire experience is the need for early preparation, he said.</p><p>Fire crews should be ready to fight fires as soon as the snow starts melting as opposed to late May and June, de Jong said.</p><p>"You've got to be ready and you've got to be ready that fires can start in May and June,'' he said.</p><p>De Jong said the major difference between the forest fires of last summer and the ravaging infernos of 2003 was that the fires of 2004 burned forests as opposed to neighbourhoods.</p><p>The 2,334 fires in 2004 burned a total of 230,000 hectares. In 2003, there were 2,519 fires and they consumed 265,000 hectares.</p><p>The government spent almost $156 million fighting forest fires in 2004.</p><p>Twelve evacuation alerts were issued affecting 6,175 people.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20041005CPCPD9880</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2004</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4DGH-TT90-01G6-91Y8-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="445"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2004 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="05" month="10" year="2004"><dateText>October 5, 2004 Tuesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="organization"><classificationItem score="64"><className>FORESTS MINISTRY </className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; FORESTRY; POLITICS;</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="92"><classCode>ST000DOX0</classCode><className>WILDFIRES</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX000631</classCode><className>ENVIRONMENTAL ACCIDENTS & DISASTERS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX000726</classCode><className>FIRES</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX001987</classCode><className>FORESTS & WOODLANDS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="78"><classCode>STX001922</classCode><className>ACCIDENTS & DISASTERS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="73"><classCode>ST00096SZ</classCode><className>PRESS CONFERENCES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem score="79"><classCode>ST000DRDO</classCode><className>PRESS AGENCY RELEASES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="state"><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>GS168</classCode><className>BRITISH COLUMBIA, CANADA</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="country"><classificationItem score="92"><classCode>GC339</classCode><className>CANADA</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

urn:contentItem:5VWT-19M1-JDH1-C3JR-00000-00Opposition takes aim at provincial budget over cuts to health units and high-speed rail2019-04-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisPOLITICSPg. 0Opposition takes aim at provincial budget over cuts to health units and high-speed railRob Ferguson

Moves to reduce the number of health units across the province will hinder efforts to monitor outbreaks, New Democrats warned, as opposition parties took a deeper look at the Ontario government's spring budget that also signalled a slowdown on high-speed rail.

"There's no way you can take 35 health agencies and whittle them down to 10 and make things better," NDP Leader Andrea Horwath said Monday of the consolidation aimed at saving $200 million over the next three years.

Health Minister Christine Elliott defended the change outlined in last Thursday's budget, saying it was recommended to the previous Liberal government and will help modernize a system in which some smaller health units have had difficulty recruiting employees.

"We want to make sure that our health units are going to be appropriately staffed and are going to be able to respond quickly in cases of emergency," she told the Legislature, maintaining a smaller number of health units with bigger staffs will be easier to mobilize.

"There are situations in Ontario where we're having outbreaks of things like tuberculosis, measles, people not getting their children vaccinated. That is an important role that public health will continue to play."

The budget cut funding for more than a dozen government ministries including environment, Indigenous Affairs and natural resources. It also "paused" capital funding for high-speed rail that the previous Liberal government of Kathleen Wynne proposed would reach London in 2025 and Windsor in 2031 at a cost of $60 million per kilometre.

"A lot of the people in southwestern Ontario were telling me over the weekend they're worried the project is dead," said Green Leader Mike Schreiner, whose Guelph riding was slated to get a stop on the 350-kilometre line Wynne kick-started in 2017 with an environmental assessment.

Citing concerns in rural areas that high-speed rail, with trains travelling on new and existing track at speeds of 250 km/h, would eliminate "countless hectares of prime agricultural land in one of Canada's richest farm belts" and restrict access to homes and fields, the Progressive Conservative government will instead look at ways to boost train speeds and service levels on existing lines.

Ways to improve bus services will also be considered as the government pledges to unveil a transportation plan for southwestern Ontario by next fall.

The Liberals had touted high-speed rail as a game-changer for southwestern Ontario, which is home to seven million people and 60 per cent of the provincial economy. The line would have made it possible, for example, for people from London to become daily commuters into Toronto with a 73-minute trip.

Cabinet ministers cautioned against reading too much into opposition criticisms of budget cuts in their departments, although interim Liberal Leader John Fraser said line-by-line details won't be available to the public until government spending estimates are released later this month.

With his envelope being reduced about one-third, Environment Minister Rod Phillips said "a little over 95 per cent of that" was from the summer elimination of the previous Liberal government's cap-and-trade program and ending the Drive Clean vehicle emissions testing program.

"We're making sure that we're protecting inspections and health and safety," Phillips said. "But yes, over time, we will find efficiencies."

Officials said the reduction of almost half in the Indigenous Affairs budget does not reflect the value of land claim settlements that may be reached this year and a trimming of more than $100 million in the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reflects only base funding for forest fire fighting - a cost that can rise substantially depending on the severity of the upcoming summer forest fire season.

Rob Ferguson is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics. Follow him on Twitter: @robferguson1

urn:contentItem:5VWV-57D1-DY91-K02M-00000-00Opposition slams health-care cuts2019-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6Opposition slams health-care cutsMinister argues reduced units with larger staff is easier to mobilizeRob Ferguson Queen's Park Bureau

Moves to reduce the number of health units across the province will hinder efforts to monitor outbreaks, New Democrats warned, as opposition parties took a deeper look at the Ontario government's spring budget that also signalled a slowdown on high-speed rail.

"There's no way you can take 35 health agencies and whittle them down to 10 and make things better," NDP Leader Andrea Horwath said Monday of the consolidation aimed at saving $200 million over the next three years.

Health Minister Christine Elliott defended the change outlined in last Thursday's budget, saying it was recommended to the previous Liberal government and will help modernize a system in which some smaller health units have had difficulty recruiting employees.

"We want to make sure that our health units are going to be appropriately staffed and are going to be able to respond quickly in cases of emergency," she told the Legislature, maintaining a smaller number of health units with bigger staffs will be easier to mobilize.

"There are situations in Ontario where we're having outbreaks of things like tuberculosis, measles, people not getting their children vaccinated.

"That is an important role that public health will continue to play."

The budget cut funding for more than a dozen government ministries including environment, Indigenous Affairs and natural resources.

It also "paused" capital funding for high-speed rail that the previous Liberal government of Kathleen Wynne proposed would reach London in 2025 and Windsor in 2031 at a cost of $60 million per kilometre.

"A lot of the people in southwestern Ontario were telling me over the weekend they're worried the project is dead," said Green Leader Mike Schreiner, whose Guelph riding was slated to get a stop on the 350-kilometre line Wynne kick-started in 2017 with an environmental assessment.

Citing concerns in rural areas that high-speed rail, with trains travelling on new and existing track at speeds of 250 km/h, would eliminate "countless hectares of prime agricultural land in one of Canada's richest farm belts" and restrict access to homes and fields, the Progressive Conservative government will instead look at ways to boost train speeds and service levels on existing lines.

Ways to improve bus services will also be considered as the government pledges to unveil a transportation plan for southwestern Ontario by next fall.

The Liberals had touted high-speed rail as a game-changer for southwestern Ontario, which is home to seven million people and 60 per cent of the provincial economy. The line would have made it possible, for example, for people from London to become daily commuters into Toronto with a 73-minute trip.

Cabinet ministers cautioned against reading too much into opposition criticisms of budget cuts in their departments, although interim Liberal Leader John Fraser said line-by-line details won't be available to the public until government spending estimates are released later this month.

With his envelope being reduced about one-third, Environment Minister Rod Phillips said "a little over 95 per cent of that" was from the summer elimination of the previous Liberal government's cap-and-trade program and ending the Drive Clean vehicle emissions testing program.

"We're making sure that we're protecting inspections and health and safety," Phillips said. "But yes, over time, we will find efficiencies."

Officials said the reduction of almost half in the Indigenous Affairs budget does not reflect the value of land claim settlements that may be reached this year and a trimming of more than $100 million in the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reflects only base funding for forest fire fighting - a cost that can rise substantially depending on the severity of the upcoming summer forest fire season.

A7</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest-fire cloud forces two jets to land at Pearson</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Jack Lakey Toronto Star</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>The pilots of two commercial jets made emergency landings at Pearson International Airport yesterday after smelling smoke on board from the huge Yellowstone National Park forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The massive high-level cloud from the Yellowstone fire and others in the western United States covered much of central North America yesterday, and other pilots reported poor visibility in some areas.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Sunset in Metro tonight will likely take on a hazy, orange glow, similar to hot weather, an Environment Canada official said.</p><p>An Air Canada flight en route from Toronto to Miami was over Cleveland yesterday morning when the pilot decided to turn back after passengers said they smelled smoke, a spokesman said.</p><p>The Boeing 767 aircraft, with 138 passengers aboard, was met by emergency vehicles and evacuated, but no signs of fire were found.</p><p>Officials later determined that the smell was caused by smoke brought into the cabin by the on-board air exchange system.</p><p>An American Airlines flight en route from New York's La Guardia airport to Toronto also encountered similar difficulties and made an emergency landing at Pearson, a Transport Canada spokesman said.</p><p>"We understand that at one point, visibility over London (Ont.) was nearly zero," she said.</p><p>An official at Pearson's air traffic control tower said the smoke posed no danger to air traffic.</p><p>At altitudes of 16,000 to 25,000 feet - above the cloud cover - the smoke in many areas is thick, brown, smelly and looks "like a large glob" on weather satellite pictures, weather officials said.</p><p>The smoke is covering an area bounded to the west by Montana and Yellowstone National Park, Sault Ste. Marie and Kingston, Ont., to the north and east, and to the south in a line extending approximately from New York city, officials said.</p><p>Fires have burned out of control at Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming for about three months.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4706-DYT0-01G6-8387-00000-00<published>1997-12-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Forest-Fire, ; EDS: UPDATES with Granum residents being told they can return home; Member photos requested; Families evacuated from forest fire in foothills; grass fire on plains</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By The Canadian Press</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Two raging forest fires and an out-of-control brush fire burned several homes in west-central Alberta and forced the brief evacuation of a small town in the province's south Sunday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Near Hinton, about 300 kilometres west of Edmonton, a handful of ranches were destroyed by a blaze believed to have started late Saturday night when an electrical pole toppled over and sparked grass left tinder-dry by the warm weather and snow-free conditions this winter.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We just woke up because the house was filling with smoke,'' said Rocky Notnes, who lost his two-storey log home, several cars and a garage to the fire.</p><p>"We went outside and saw the fire. The wind was so strong we knew it could come this way, and then as we were speaking, there was just fire literally dropping from the sky.''</p><p>On Sunday afternoon, the entire population of Granum, a town of about 350 in southwestern Alberta, was ordered evacuated as a grass fire burned unchecked.</p><p>However, later in the day it appeared the town had escaped damage and residents were told they could return home.</p><p>Ernie Patterson, mayor of nearby Claresholm, said firefighting efforts and a lucky shift in the wind stopped the blaze right on the edge of Granum.</p><p>"We've had no snow,'' Patterson said of local conditions. "The forest fire hazard is extremely high.''</p><p>The fire, which officials said had burned 100 square kilometres of land, also forced the closure of Highway 2 and prompted women and children to flee the Keho Hutterite colony.</p><p>Spokeswoman Barbara Wurtz said colony members evacuated to another colony north of Granum while the men stayed behind to work on saving a pig barn.</p><p>"While the sun was out we could see what seemed like a mixture of billowing sand and smoke,'' said Eileen Cooper of Barons, a town just east of Granum.</p><p>"At one time the sun was rust-red.''</p><p>Visitors and workers at a popular tourist attraction called Head-Smashed-In-Buffalo-Jump were also evacuated as a precaution.</p><p>Emergency workers in the much larger community of Fort Macleod were on standby for evacuation almost all afternoon but no order was given. Mayor Wes Olmstead said buses were ready just in case the wind shifted.</p><p>Smoke from the fire could be smelled 50 kilometres away in Lethbridge.</p><p>Near Hinton, Evert Smith of Alberta's Land and Forest Service said one of the two fires covered 500 hectares north of the community. The second blaze, about 1,500 hectares in size, blazed about 30 kilometres south of the town.</p><p>Although the fires were being driven by 80-kilometre winds, neither was expected to menace the community of about 10,000.</p><p>Six water tankers, four helicopters and eight ground crews were fighting the fires. Sixteen different fire departments from different communities were fighting the grass fire, which started near Pincher Creek on Sunday morning and moved more than 50 kilometres in five hours.</p><p>Lethbridge fire platoon chief Don Carpenter said Sunday afternoon he didn't know who's in control.</p><p>Forestry officer Dennis Halladay said every jurisdiction was fighting it on their own: "We'll look later this evening to see if we'll continue that way or pull it all together.''</p><p>Although most forest fires occur in the summer, winter fires do occur along the foothills, areas often blown bare and dry by chinook winds gusting over the mountains.</p><p>"Along the eastern slopes, we have records of fires in all 12 months of the year,'' said Smith.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5VW1-DP21-F103-32V4-00000-00UBC Okanagan professor examines flood risk2019-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSUBC Okanagan professor examines flood risk

After a winter with below-average temperatures, Okanagan residents are beginning to see the light at the end of the tunnel-and it just so happens to be the sun.

The last two spring and summer seasons had their share of environmental challenges. With wet springs followed by smoky summers seemingly becoming the norm, UBC Okanagan's David Scott provides his opinion on what's in store for 2019.

Scott is an associate professor in earth, environmental, and geographic sciences at UBC Okanagan and the Forest Renewal British Columbia Research Chair in Watershed Management.

What is the snowpack currently sitting at in the Okanagan Valley?

Right now, it's at about 80 per cent of normal, which is pretty low and about half of what we had in last year's record-breaking season. The first of April is usually an indication of the whole season, so we are well below average and the snowpack is already starting to disappear.

READ MORE: UBCO students create club to tackle campus food waste

READ MORE: Fast-talking UBC Okanagan students to compete for $6,000

Are there risks associated with that number?

Yes, there are still some risks, but not from the snowpack alone. Two years ago, when we had large scale flooding in the Okanagan, the snowpack was around 85 per cent at this time of year. It probably went up to about 105 per cent before it started to really melt-but that on its own wasn't what caused the flooding. The problem was the above average rainfall in May and June. So the risk we're facing right now is that we don't know what the weather will do or how much rain might fall.

Are snowpack and rain the two main factors that lead to flooding?

Those are the big ones, yes. The thing about the snowpack is that it gives us a predictable risk. Last year, we had a well-above-average snowpack at this time of year, we were at 150 per cent of normal. This sounds like a concerning number, but it meant that people could plan for a lot of water. They lowered the level of the lake so that when the snow melt did come, it was accommodated and we didn't have the anticipated flooding in Kelowna.

There are other minor risks as well, for example how quickly temperatures rise as that will accelerate the melt. But I think the biggest risk is rain, because we never know how much is coming and rain accelerates melting.

READ MORE: UBCO warns of man suspected of hassling women on campus

READ MORE: UBCO addressing on-campus student housing needs

In your opinion, what will the 2019 flooding season look like in the Okanagan?

Given the normal pattern of weather, I don't think we have a big risk this year. There's always a risk for minor flooding in some areas, but compared to previous years, I'd say we have very little to worry about.

Is there a connection between the snowpack, flooding and the forest fire season that follows it?

There is a connection-but I consider it to be a weak one. When we look at last year, we had an abnormally high snowpack, which does start us off will a fully-wetted watershed. But once that excess water drained away, we had a very dry season. We entered the forest fire season with a fully recharged soil, but it didn't amount for much come the end of the summer. So, yes, it can give you a buffer at the beginning, but you need to have rain during the summer to keep that risk down.

Forest Service spokeswoman said Thursday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Spokeswoman Wendy Stewart said firefighters have been aided by cooler temperatures and calmer winds in their battle against the Ware fire.</p><p>The small town of Ware, about 900 kilometres north of Vancouver, was evacuated when the fire broke out last weekend. The 250 residents fled to another village while some 130 firefighters continue battling the blaze.</p><p>The fire is now estimated at 10,000 hectares - up from 6,200 hectares. The change resulted mostly on maps after fire officials revised the boundaries of the blaze. About 170 firefighters are battling the Ware fire.</p><p>So far this year, the government has spent $4.2 million fighting forest fires, compared to $2.2 million to this date in 1994.</p><p>There have been 554 fires to date this year, up from 415 in the corresponding period in 1994.</p><p>Of the 554 fires, 548 were caused by humans.</p><p>Meanwhile, a 3,500-hectare fire burning near Quesnel could be contained today, officials said. More than 100 firefighters are working on that blaze.</p><p>Thirty firefighters are battling a quick-burning, 35-hectare fire near Mable Lake, 16 kilometres northeast of Enderby in the north Okanagan.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Natives flee as forest fire threatens homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Almost 400 natives fled a remote northwestern Ontario reserve with little more than the clothes on their backs Sunday as a ferocious forest fire threatened to incinerate their community.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"You can bet they're scared," said Michael Power, mayor of Geraldton, Ont., a small town 160 kilometres northeast of Thunder Bay, which prepared to welcome yet another community forced to flee fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"They could lose their homes and many of these people have never hopped on a plane before, let alone been to an intersection with stop lights."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CANADIAN PRESS</p></bodyText></section><p>Residents of Wunnummin Lake were evacuated by three Hercules airplanes as an inferno moved within two kilometres of their community Sunday.</p><p>The blaze was sparked by lightning Saturday and travelled about 2,000 times faster than most fires do, said Dave Jackson, of the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>It was the second time in four days that Geraldton, a town of 2,600, has thrown open its arms to a northwestern Ontario community.</p><p>Almost 350 residents of Bearskin Lake, about 500 kilometres northwest of Geraldton, were forced to abandon their community Thursday as a massive fire moved in.</p><p>Residents from the two reserves -- about 130 kilometres apart -- were to spend the night in a high school and a municipal arena.</p><p>While the people of Wunnummin Lake got acquainted with the townsfolk, residents of Bearskin Lake were eager to say goodbye.</p><p>Homesick</p><p>"I'm really homesick," said Mary Beardy, 22, who fled the reserve with her parents and her four sisters who are sleeping on cots in an ice rink. "But we're glad we're safe."</p><p>There were 102 forest fires burning across Ontario on Sunday, most in scattered pockets along a 900-kilometre stretch of northwestern Ontario, from Red Lake east to Hudson's Bay. But the 1,000 weary firefighters got help from other parts of Canada.</p><p>British Columbia sent in about 30 firefighters and Newfoundland dispatched two of its water bombers to the area.</p><p>They joined up with nine CL-215 water bombers, five Twin Otter bombers and about 60 helicopters already helping battle what many describe as the worst batch of blazes to whip Ontario forestland in a decade.</p><p>While firefighters tried to save northwestern Ontario, two blazes raged out of control in Alberta.</p><p>Rain arrives</p><p>But forestry officials in Alberta declared a victory when they got the mammoth Mariana Lakes fire under control.</p><p>Torrents of rain and hail washed over the fire that has twice cut off the main road into Fort McMurray.</p><p>As the weather system swept northeast, rain and higher humidity levels arrived to the relief of fighters in the Northwest Territories and northern Saskatchewan.</p><p>But none of the roughly 350 evacuees from Stanley Mission, about 240 kilometres north of Prince Albert, were expected to return home.</p><p>In Manitoba, firefighters and residents hoped the rain would reach them. About 78 fires were burning in Manitoba, seven out of control.</p><p>Temperatures had soared Saturday as high as 38 C. But the muggy air kept fires from spreading quickly and no communities were directly threatened.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5VW1-DP21-F103-32TJ-00000-00UBC Okanagan professor examines flood risk2019-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSUBC Okanagan professor examines flood risk

After a winter with below-average temperatures, Okanagan residents are beginning to see the light at the end of the tunnel-and it just so happens to be the sun.

The last two spring and summer seasons had their share of environmental challenges. With wet springs followed by smoky summers seemingly becoming the norm, UBC Okanagan's David Scott provides his opinion on what's in store for 2019.

Scott is an associate professor in earth, environmental, and geographic sciences at UBC Okanagan and the Forest Renewal British Columbia Research Chair in Watershed Management.

What is the snowpack currently sitting at in the Okanagan Valley?

Right now, it's at about 80 per cent of normal, which is pretty low and about half of what we had in last year's record-breaking season. The first of April is usually an indication of the whole season, so we are well below average and the snowpack is already starting to disappear.

READ MORE: UBCO students create club to tackle campus food waste

READ MORE: Fast-talking UBC Okanagan students to compete for $6,000

Are there risks associated with that number?

Yes, there are still some risks, but not from the snowpack alone. Two years ago, when we had large scale flooding in the Okanagan, the snowpack was around 85 per cent at this time of year. It probably went up to about 105 per cent before it started to really melt-but that on its own wasn't what caused the flooding. The problem was the above average rainfall in May and June. So the risk we're facing right now is that we don't know what the weather will do or how much rain might fall.

Are snowpack and rain the two main factors that lead to flooding?

Those are the big ones, yes. The thing about the snowpack is that it gives us a predictable risk. Last year, we had a well-above-average snowpack at this time of year, we were at 150 per cent of normal. This sounds like a concerning number, but it meant that people could plan for a lot of water. They lowered the level of the lake so that when the snow melt did come, it was accommodated and we didn't have the anticipated flooding in Kelowna.

There are other minor risks as well, for example how quickly temperatures rise as that will accelerate the melt. But I think the biggest risk is rain, because we never know how much is coming and rain accelerates melting.

READ MORE: UBCO warns of man suspected of hassling women on campus

READ MORE: UBCO addressing on-campus student housing needs

In your opinion, what will the 2019 flooding season look like in the Okanagan?

Given the normal pattern of weather, I don't think we have a big risk this year. There's always a risk for minor flooding in some areas, but compared to previous years, I'd say we have very little to worry about.

Is there a connection between the snowpack, flooding and the forest fire season that follows it?

There is a connection-but I consider it to be a weak one. When we look at last year, we had an abnormally high snowpack, which does start us off will a fully-wetted watershed. But once that excess water drained away, we had a very dry season. We entered the forest fire season with a fully recharged soil, but it didn't amount for much come the end of the summer. So, yes, it can give you a buffer at the beginning, but you need to have rain during the summer to keep that risk down.

urn:contentItem:5XW2-S691-JDH1-C1R1-00000-00Canada sends two more groups of firefighters to fight Australian wildfires2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A6Canada sends two more groups of firefighters to fight Australian wildfires'They've been here for us and we'd like to be here for them'The Canadian Press

Firefighters from across Canada are on their way to Australia to bolster Canadians already assisting the country in the battle against devastating wildfires.

Stephen Tulle, duty officer with the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, says a group of 15 set out for Queensland Monday, while another group of 21 will fly out later in the week. He says the contingent of Canadian wildfire specialists stationed in Queensland and New South Wales will reach 87 by Jan. 4. This is the first time that Canada has sent firefighters to Australia, although Tulle says crews from Down Under have visited here and were vital in helping British Columbia handle widespread wildfires in 2017 and 2018.

The Canadian contingent is made up of volunteers from B.C., Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, Yukon and Parks Canada.

The Australian wildfires have killed 10 people and destroyed 1,000 homes across the country in the past few months.

Tulle says the Canadians will primarily be performing fire-manager duties, related to command, planning, logistics and aviation management.

Many of the Canadians are already familiar with their Australian counterparts, Tulle said.

"It's like old homecoming week," he said.

"They're down there and they say, 'Hey, we worked together in British Columbia in 2018.' And so, they do know each other. They do have those contacts and those relationships."

Canadian firefighters will spend about six weeks in Australia before returning home and Tulle said Canada will continue to send crews as long as volunteers can be found, and Australia is requesting help.

"Our people, kudos to them, have been standing up saying, 'Yeah, you know what, they've been here for us and we'd like to be here for them.'"

urn:contentItem:470T-WM80-01G6-84W2-00000-00<published>1995-06-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>QUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Forest-Fire-Costs ; With AM-Forest-Fire-Ont, Bgt NL; Forest fires could cost Ontario's economy up to $92 million</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Deborah McDougall</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>RED LAKE, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>RED LAKE, Ont. (CP) - Forest fires ravaging northwestern Ontario could end up burning a $920-million hole in the province's economy, government foresters said Wednesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire whipping through precious forestland could end up costing the economy that much in lost jobs, taxes and other spinoff effects, says John Huybers of the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>The province could lose up to $92 million alone from the fees it charges companies to cut down Crown land, says Huybers.</p><p>"It's a real, real shame,'' said Huybers, shaking his head, as yet another helicopter whisks away firefighters to one of more than 250 fires in Ontario.</p><p>Foresters base their prediction on the value of land burning and how much has been destroyed so far.</p><p>Fires had destroyed more than 2,210 square kilometres of forestland by Wednesday. Another 2,000-plus square kilometres were ablaze.</p><p>A lot of the land that's been destroyed was traditional hunting and trapping grounds for aboriginals, said Bob Thomas of the Natural Resources Ministry.</p><p>Skies are blanketed in acrid white smoke. A satellite photograph showed the smoke covered almost as much area as Hudson Bay.</p><p>Foresters are watching the woods they spent their life rejuvenating go up in smoke.</p><p>"It's heart wrenching,'' said Gary McKibbon, a forester for Avenor Inc., who's spent the last 15 years carefully cultivating woodlands in the area.</p><p>"I've put my heart and soul into this, everything from planting to aerial seeding, and now it's all being chewed up by fire.''</p><p>His concerns aren't just personal.</p><p>Jobs could be on the line for Avenor's two woodlands operations in Dryden and Thunder Bay, Ont. depending on how much of the crown land it was depending upon gets destroyed, he said.</p><p>He bristles over the prospect folks in southern Ontario might not care about forestland so remote, and removed from urban areas.</p><p>McKibbon insists Ontario taxpayers consider what the fires could end up costing them in the long run.</p><p>If companies aren't paying the provincial goverment stumpage fees for the wood they cut because forestland is destroyed, that means fewer tax dollars are collected to build schools and renovate hospitals, he said.</p><p>"Everybody's got a stake in his, no matter where they live,'' said McKibbon.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7YMB-FG11-2R4S-J519-00000-00Forest Fire in Atikamekw Territory: The AFNQL Demands Actions from the Federal Government2010-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisAttention News EditorsForest Fire in Atikamekw Territory: The AFNQL Demands Actions from the Federal GovernmentQUEBEC June 3

The Chiefs of the First Nations, meeting today in Quebec City, during a meeting of the Assembly of First Nations of Quebec and Labrador (AFNQL), denounced the bureaucratic attitude of the federal government in face of the crisis facing members of the Atikamekw nation, who have been victims of forest fires. "This is a humanitarian crisis recognized by everyone except the federal government. Given this extraordinary situation, the government must immediately adopt special measures to provide relief to the populations involved", stated AFNQL Chief, Ghislain Picard.

Approximately 139,000 hectares of forest land are being ravaged by forest fires, which have had an impact on the Atikamekw communities of Manawan, Wemotaci and Obedjiwan, whose members had to be evacuated. It is still not known when it will be possible for the 1,300 members of the Atikamekw community of Wemotaci to return to their homes. Many will return to homes that have been damaged by the fires. "The impacts are important and the situation has to be considered as a humanitarian crisis. We are demanding that the federal government take immediate action to respond to the crisis that has struck our Atikamekw brothers and sisters", stated Chief Picard.

About the AFNQL:

The AFNQL is a regional organization representing 43 Chiefs of the First Nations of Quebec and Labrador. For more information: www.apnql-afnql.com.



CONTACT:Éric Cardinal, Communications Advisor, (514) 258-2315 (cell.), eric@cardinalcommunication.com

urn:contentItem:5XW3-9761-DY9S-T025-00000-00Canada sends two more groups of Canadians to Australia to help fight wildfires2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNATIONALCanada sends two more groups of Canadians to Australia to help fight wildfiresCanadian wildfire crews travel to AustraliaThe Canadian Press

WINNIPEG - Firefighters from across Canada are on their way to Australia to bolster Canadians already assisting the country in the battle against devastating wildfires.

Stephen Tulle, duty officer with the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, says a group of 15 set out for Queensland Monday, while another group of 21 will fly out later in the week.

He says the contingent of Canadian wildfire specialists stationed in Queensland and New South Wales will reach 87 by Jan. 4.

This is the first time that Canada has sent firefighters to Australia, although Tulle says crews from Down Under have visited here and were vital in helping British Columbia handle widespread wildfires in 2017 and 2018.

The Canadian contingent is made up of male and female volunteers from B.C., Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, Yukon and Parks Canada.

The Australian wildfires have killed 10 people and destroyed 1,000 homes across the country in the past few months.

Tulle says the Canadians will primarily be performing fire-manager duties, related to command, planning, logistics and aviation management.

Many of the Canadians are already familiar with their Australian counterparts, Tulle said.

"It's like old homecoming week," he said.

"They're down there and they say, 'Hey, we worked together in British Columbia in 2018.' And so, they do know each other. They do have those contacts and those relationships."

Canadian firefighters will spend about six weeks in Australia before returning home and Tulle said Canada will continue to send crews as long as volunteers can be found, and Australia is requesting help.

"Our people, kudos to them, have been standing up saying, 'Yeah, you know what, they've been here for us and we'd like to be here for them.' "

This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 30, 2019

urn:contentItem:5SXB-KRF1-JDH3-G4KF-00000-00Grundy Lake evacuates, says MPP Miller, tours area with Premier Ford2018-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Grundy Lake evacuates, says MPP Miller, tours area with Premier Ford

PARRY SOUND -Grundy Lake Provincial Park has been evacuated.

The Key River fire has grown again to 7,300 ha and is now "right up by Grundy Lake Provincial Park" and the CN Railway, said Parry Sound-Muskoka MPP Norm Miller.

"They have just now had to evacuate Grundy Lake Provincial Park," said Miller. "I think it has just happened or is happening."

The fire started somewhere in Henvey Inlet First Nation last Wednesday, July 18, said Miller, who went down the Key River today with the Minister of Natural Resources. Premier Doug Ford was also on site but didn't take the boat tour.

Miller was on his way back to West Parry Sound just before 6 p.m. Friday night and said the exact location and cause of the fire is under investigation by the MNRF.

"(The fire) went north and jumped the Key River (earlier on), so the MNR who were in charge of the evacuation were describing he decision they made to evacuate all the cottagers, how they had to get them out when the fire was raging on both sides of the Key River. They had them out on the edge of Georgian Bay and they had to decide with all the boats with 70 people in them, whether they brought them in the Key River, with two fires burning on either side, or whether they risked going down to the coast to Britt. But some of the boats were pretty small boats so they had to take hat into consideration as well."

What was decided, Miller said, was to go back up the Key River though the area that was burning, to Highway 69 and the local marina with support of water bombers.

Accompanied by Jeff Yurek, Minister of Natural Resources and Forestry, MIller and Ford met with people in the affected communities today, as well as with teams that are fighting the fires and managing the evacuation process.

"It's a terrible thing to have to flee your home because of a forest fire," said Ford. "These fires have shown how communities in Ontario come together in times of need."

Ford praised forest fire teams working with the Ontario Provincial Police, community leaders and other agencies to battle fires in the Parry Sound area and other parts of the province. As well, he recognized the help Ontario is receiving from beyond its borders.

"I want to thank all of the courageous men and women from near and far for helping us respond to this emergency," said Ford. "And I am grateful to the premiers of provinces that are helping Ontario, as well as leaders in the U.S. and Mexico who are providing assistance. We are working side by side as one united community."

urn:contentItem:460W-4KS0-01G6-9205-00000-00<published>2001-08-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>TRAVEL</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>B.C. government Web site gives forest fire information</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VANCOUVER (CP) _ Anyone planning an outdoors vacation in British Columbia might want to look at the forest fire Web site run by the B.C. Forestry Ministry (<url normalizedValue="http://www.for.gov.bc.ca/protect">www.for.gov.bc.ca/protect</url>). </p><p nitf:lede="true">Besides giving an up-to-date overview of where fires are burning in the province, the site offers information on campfire regulations, colour-coded maps showing the danger ratings of various regions, tips on fire safety and forest fire statistics.</p><p nitf:lede="true">British museums mark anniversary of Agatha Christie's death, while Mousetrap plays on</p><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON (CP) _ The British Museum is marking the 25th anniversary of writer Agatha Christie's death with a look at her life as an amateur archeologist.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mystery in Mesopotamia, running from Nov. 8 to next March, will feature exhibits relating to her interest in the subject, artifacts and ephemera from the Middle Eastern excavations on which she worked, and explain how she met her future husband, Max Mallowan, at one of the digs.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Some of her best known books, including Murder on the Orient Express, Death on the Nile and Murder in Mesopotamia, were based on her travels in the Middle East. (On the Web: <url normalizedValue="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk">www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk</url>.) </p><p>Meanwhile, Christie's The Mousetrap, the longest-running stage production in the world, begins its 50th anniversary year on Nov. 25, 2001. St. Martin's Theatre in London plans a year-long celebration of this enduring murder mystery, culminating in a gala performance on Nov. 25, 2002.</p><p>And in her birthplace of Torquay in southwest England, Christie is being remembered at the Torquay Museum. The museum has undergone a refurbishment which includes its Christie displays, along with a reconstruction of a Victorian farmhouse kitchen and archeological artifacts from a nearby cavern. The Christie showcases feature costumes from the Poirot and Miss Marple TV series, along with her books and theatre programs from around the world. (On the Web: <url normalizedValue="http://www.theenglishriviera.co.uk">www.theenglishriviera.co.uk</url>.) </p><p>Fish and chips come wrapped in news from Halifax</p><p>TORONTO (CP) _ You don't have to go to Nova Scotia to get your deep-fried pepperoni. A new pub in Toronto caters to people looking for that delicacy and other traditional East Coast fare.</p><p>Also on the menu at the Duke of Argyle, in the city's entertainment district, are fish cakes with green tomato chow chow, while fish and chips come to the table wrapped in a newspaper cone from the Halifax Daily News.</p><p> Visitors to Toronto can now experience genuine East Coast cuisine, entertainment and hospitality,'' said pub general manager Natalie Baker.</p><p>U.S. Park Service to bar nine cruise ships from entering Alaska's Glacier Bay</p><p>ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) _ The U.S. National Park Service plans to bar nine cruise ships from entering Glacier Bay National Park in Southeast Alaska this summer for environmental reasons.</p><p>Agency spokesman John Quinley said the action brings the park service into compliance with an order issued Aug. 3 by U.S. District Judge James Singleton.</p><p>The decrease will affect about 13,500 cruise ship passengers this tourist season.</p><p>Under the cutback, HollandAmerica cruises are being cut by five, Princess Cruises by two, Norwegian Cruise Line by one and World Explorer Cruises by one.</p><p>The cutback is less drastic than the barring of 32 ships that some people had anticipated after Singleton's decision.</p><p>The judge's order caught many people in the tourism industry off-guard because they expected the cuts to begin next year, not in the middle of the tourist season.</p><p>In his decision, Singleton told the Park Service to slash the number of cruise ships allowed into Glacier Bay immediately in response to a federal appeals court ruling. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals found that the Park Service erred in allowing a 72 per cent increase in cruise ship entries in 1997 without having done a major environment review. While the court ordered ship visits cut, it left it to Singleton to implement the order.</p><p>Princess and HollandAmerica, the companies with the largest number of ships calling at Glacier Bay, said they will divert ships to other glacier-laden spots in the southeast, such as Tracy Arm south of Juneau and the Hubbard Glacier near Yakutat.</p><p>Harley-Davidson to mark 100th anniversary with yearlong celebration</p><p>MILWAUKEE (AP) _ Harley-Davidson, the largest maker of motorcycles in the United States, is planning a yearlong celebration of its 100th anniversary, beginning with a five-continent road tour and ending with a party in Milwaukee the company expects will draw 200,000 people.</p><p> It's going to be big, it's going to be worldwide,'' said Kathleen Lawler, vice-president of communications for the firm.</p><p>The celebration will kick off in July 2002 after a Harley dealer meeting in Milwaukee.</p><p>The company said it will welcome Harley owners and enthusiasts to join the Open Road Tour, which will include weekend-long stops in North America, Australia and Japan. The tour will end in 2003 with two events in Europe.</p><p>The celebration will then return to the United States, where riders will join tours to Milwaukee for the grand finale with a big-name concert on Aug. 31, 2003, along the Lake Michigan shoreline.</p><p>Harley said it is also planning celebrations across Wisconsin before the final bash. Ticket information will be released early next year, the company said.</p><p>On the Net: Harley-Davidson, <url normalizedValue="http://www.harley-davidson.com">www.harley-davidson.com</url>; Greater Milwaukee Convention and Visitors Bureau, <url normalizedValue="http://www.officialmilwaukee.com">www.officialmilwaukee.com</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:3X1S-W6V0-00RJ-F0SN-00000-00<published>1999-02-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><broadcastInfo><show><showName>CANADA AM</showName></show><newsAnchors>Dan Matheson</newsAnchors><guests>Tawney Meiorin, Former Forest Fire Fighter</guests></broadcastInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>High Court Weighs Test for Female Forest Fire Fighters</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>MATHESON: Does the province of British Columbia discriminate against female forest fire fighters? That's the question right now before the Supreme Court of Canada. This dispute is over a fitness test that must be passed to first get a job and then to keep that job.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Tawney Meiorin, an experienced fire fighter, failed a running test and lost her job -- a test that her union says favours men. And Tawney Meiorin joins us now from Ottawa.</p><p>Good morning, Tawney.</p><p>MEIORIN: Good morning.</p><p>MATHESON: Can you tell us how you first got started as a forest fire fighter? Did you have to pass a fitness test at that time?</p><p>MEIORIN: No, I had worked with contract crews for four years and I applied [unclear] go through an interview. They wanted experience and a first-aid ticket. There was always a physical- fitness test. But at the time when they asked me I was a minute slow in the run and couldn't do all the chin-ups. And at that time they wanted my experience, my first-aid ticket and they said, "That's fine, we can get by without doing the physical-fitness test," and we weren't tested for the first two years.</p><p>MATHESON: So, you weren't tested for how long?</p><p>MEIORIN: For two years.</p><p>MATHESON: For two years. And then when you did take the test what was the part that you had trouble with? The running?</p><p>MEIORIN: The running. I was 49 seconds slow in a two-and-a-half- kilometre run that had to be done in under 11 minutes.</p><p>MATHESON: Now, many people including the Forest Service says that you must be fit, you must be able to do this run, it's a question of safety.</p><p>MEIORIN: Well, it's really funny -- a question of safety. What they're saying is a person that can run 49 seconds faster than me that's never fought a fire before in their lives is going to be safer than me on a fire. And anyone that's fought fires is saying that's absolutely ridiculous. This test has got nothing to do with knowledge and experience. And the most hazardous part of a job is now knowing what you're doing or knowing how the fire is going to react to you.</p><p>MATHESON: Now, can not the argument be made that to get from point A to point B when you're fighting a fire just takes speed, it's an absolute, it doesn't matter if you're male or female, young or old, it doesn't matter what your race or religion is, you have a certain amount of time and that's it?</p><p>MEIORIN: What are you saying? I have to run out of a fire? Is that what you're trying to tell me, or --?</p><p>MATHESON: Yes.</p><p>MEIORIN: Oh. Well, you're never going to outrun a crowning fire. It's like there's no way. And if you are going to run you're not going to run away from a fire. The safest spot is actually to run back into the fire, into the burnt-off area.</p><p>MATHESON: So, should there be no fitness test at all then?</p><p>MEIORIN: No, I don't agree that there shouldn't be a test at all. I mean, there should be a test but they should also test you on your knowledge and experience. Like how to start a fire pump or how to fall a tree or to know your fire codes -- like how dry the soil is and the humidity and how it's going to affect you. I mean, by saying that you're going to run fast is not to say that you're going to be safe on a fire at all.</p><p>MATHESON: But you don't feel there should be a fitness component then?</p><p>MEIORIN: Oh, I believe, like most of the people being hired at the time that I was being hired on were all based on past experience. Like, you work contract crews for a few years and then you get a job with the ministry of forests. It's proven in your past work experience that you're capable of doing the job.</p><p>MATHESON: Now, Tawney, your union says it wants to have two tests: one for men, and one for women which has lower standards. Do you think that's a good idea?</p><p>MEIORIN: Well, if you look at any test in any physical book and even the kinesiology course when you first take it, it states that no test should be designed without considering age and gender. And if you look at any test, a ParticipAction test right in the schools from a young age, there's always two tests. As well, the ministry of forests designed a test for the native crews where the women don't step as high as the men.</p><p>MATHESON: Tawney Meiorin, thank you very much.</p><p>MEIORIN: Thank you.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV1999</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4700-NWC0-01G6-82X4-00000-00<published>1998-05-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>QUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Ont-Forest-Fire, ; EDS: RECASTS lead; ADDS quotes, details; With AM-Prairie-Forest-Fires; Evacuees return to village</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>THUNDER BAY, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>THUNDER BAY, Ont. (CP) - Residents of a remote village near here saw the return of some evacuees Tuesday but were prepared for another quick getaway if a nearby forest fire worsens.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 50 people, mostly elderly and those with breathing problems, left Gull Bay First Nation, about 150 kilometres north of Thunder Bay, on Monday night.</p><p>They were bused about 60 kilometres north to the small community of Armstrong to escape smoke from a fire burning over 17,000 hectares just south of Gull Bay.</p><p>"It kind of looked scary last night,'' band chief Oliver Poile said Tuesday. "The fire was just burning at the tree tops.''</p><p>But Dave Jackson, a provincial fire information officer, said Tuesday the wind had shifted and was blowing the smoke away from the village of about 400 people on Lake Nipigon.</p><p>Meanwhile, the fire is burning back on itself, he said. The weather was also co-operating, with cooler temperatures and light rain reported around Gull Bay.</p><p>The evacuees, who had been put up in a CN Rail bunkhouse, were told it was safe to go home.</p><p>"Armstrong is not really equipped to have people brought in for a long stay,'' said Diane Laybourne, chairwoman of Armstrong's local services board.</p><p>She said residents could be airlifted to Thunder Bay today if the fire continued to threaten the community.</p><p>About 100 firefighters are fighting the flames, with two water bombers and four helicopters.</p><p>Fire crews spent much of Tuesday regrouping and deciding how to fight the tenacious blaze.</p><p>"They're kind of stepping back and coming up with a new plan of attack,'' said Jackson.</p><p>An unusually dry April has prompted the Natural Resources Ministry to issue a fire ban in the area from Manitoba's border to the western shores of Lake Nipigon, including Thunder Bay. All fires, including campfires, are banned.</p><p>Ministry crews were escorting residents, food and other supplies up and down Highway 527 from Thunder Bay to Armstrong on Tuesday. Convoys are to continue today but the highway remains closed to regular traffic.</p><p>Near Kenora, fire crews worked five hours Monday to extinguish a quarter-hectare fire. A CL-215 water bomber helped by dropping three loads of water on the flames.</p><p>Another forest fire north of Timmins forced the evacuation of several homes on Sunday but firefighters managed to bring it under control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XVT-TX71-JCF0-K0MJ-00000-00Australian Wildfires2019-12-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:30ZLexisNexisCTV NATIONAL NEWS23:00:00 ETOMAR SACHEDINAAustralian Wildfires

OMAR SACHEDINA: Firefighters in Australia got a break today from devastating wildfires after the weather turned mild and wet. But the relief won't last. Flames are still raging. And as CTV's Molly Thomas reports, conditions are about to get worse.

MOLLY THOMAS (Reporter): Water bombers to the rescue to fight ferocious flames that can reach as high as a 20-storey building, and so much smoke, this firefighter almost disappears.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: The fire doesn't stop just because it's Christmas.

THOMAS: While it may not look like it, the weather was a Christmas gift for some. A trickle of rain and lower temperatures allowed some firefighters to leave the front lines.

GROUP: Merry Christmas!

THOMAS: To be served, for a change.

ALAN STEVEN (Salvation Army): I had the opportunity to make it for Christmas eve, so we're doing roast chicken and ham off the bone.

THOMAS: The majority of these men and women are unpaid volunteers, risking their lives for strangers, including a Canadian contingent of 51 providing aviation and logistical services.

STEPHEN TULLE (Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre): I've been hearing from a few of them, and they're saying they've never seen anything like this.

THOMAS: Fires have been raging for months. Eight people have lost their lives, and nearly a thousand homes have been destroyed, and more than 12 million acres of bush completely burnt. That's about three times the area destroyed in BC's record-setting fire season last year. This baby koala is being nursed back to health, but 2,000 of the native bears did not make it out alive. Now fears revolve around that changing weather. There are bush fires burning around every major city in Australia, including two that could merge into a mega fire near Sydney, Omar, with that temperature expected to spike again this weekend.

SACHEDINA: Making the battle even tougher. All right, Molly, thanks.

urn:contentItem:470T-DYH0-01G6-B4RW-00000-00<published>1995-07-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:58:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest Fire Roundup</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>(Saskatchewan-Manitoba) Rain and humid air have soothed parched forests across the country.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 18-hundred residents of towns in northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba are back home after spending as much as two weeks away.</p><p nitf:lede="true">They returned Friday and Saturday as flames that threatened their communities finally began to retreat.</p><p>About 11-hundred citizens of Leaf Rapids, Manitoba, took part in Canada Day revelry in Lynn Lake before returning to their homes, 700 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</p><p>However, firefighting efforts continue in the area. (More Lynn Lake)</p><p>Fifty residents of Lynn Lake lost their homes June 25th when fire claimed 17 mobile homes, along with a church and a garage.</p><p>Three days later, three firefighters were killed when a helicopter crashed into the Churchill River.</p><p>The homeless residents have been given temporary shelter in apartments.</p><p>Elsewhere in Manitoba, rain and high humidity have reduced the threat of fires. (Saskatchewan)</p><p>In Saskatchewan, where fire has claimed more than one-thousand square kilometres of forest, the 700 residents of Sandy Bay have been allowed home after nearly two weeks.</p><p>Fire official John Cook says cool temperatures and a lack of wind are keeping the province's 61 fires at bay.</p><p>But he says firefighters won't be able to rest easy for some time. (Ontario-Quebec)</p><p>In Ontario, the number of fires burning across the province has dwindled to 226, covering about 36-hundred square kilometres.</p><p>The number peaked at more than 400 last week.</p><p>Fires have destroyed 115 square kilometres of woodlands in Quebec, although no towns or communities are threatened. (B-C-Yukon-New Brunswick)</p><p>Heavy rain across most of B-C helped cool extreme fire conditions, though 15 new blazes were sparked by lightning.</p><p>Rain also drenched much of the fire-ravaged Yukon over the weekend.</p><p>Meanwhile, New Brunswick officials partially lifted an 11-day ban on campfires and burning permits yesterday after wet weather reduced the province's fires to six. (CP) --- bjk</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
